finding: This variant in NOL12:TRIOBP was possibly deleterious, indicating a link to congenital deafness and implicating it in hearing loss mechanisms.
title: Sex differences, cross-ancestry generalizability, and noise-smoking interactions in the polygenic architecture of hearing loss in adults

finding: Similar to rs5756795, this variant was considered potentially pathogenic in relation to the known effects of TRIOBP mutations on hearing loss.
title: Sex differences, cross-ancestry generalizability, and noise-smoking interactions in the polygenic architecture of hearing loss in adults

finding: The study demonstrated that the maternal COMT Met158Met genotype, represented by SNP rs4680, was significantly associated with early-onset preeclampsia (PE) in both African American and Caucasian subjects compared to the Val158Val and Val158Met genotypes. However, the COMT genotype did not show significant association with late-onset PE, indicating a potential risk factor specifically for early-onset cases.
title: The COMT Val158Met Polymorphism is Significantly Associated with Early Onset Preeclampsia in Both African American and Caucasian Mothers

finding: The study demonstrated that the SNP rs738409 located in the PNPLA3 gene was associated with the occurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with cirrhosis. This finding contributed to risk model predictions, indicating that individuals with specific genotypes of rs738409 had a heightened risk for developing HCC. This association supports the use of genetic factors in risk assessment models for cirrhotic patients.
title: Validation of a glycomics-based test associated with risk of HCC development in cirrhosis

finding: The SNP rs192493667 was found to be genome-wide significant in the context of multiple cancers when compared to single cancer controls (OR=1.39, P=3.6×10^-8), indicating strong association specifically in the European population group.
title: Unraveling the genetic landscape of susceptibility to multiple primary cancers

finding: Associated with long-term varenicline effectiveness, rs766169 was implicated in the genetic basis for more sustained cessation efforts.
title: Genome-wide association study of varenicline-aided smoking cessation

finding: The SNP rs2239785 was identified as a significant locus associated with diabetic macular edema (DME) risk. It resulted in a missense variant (K150E) in the gene APOL1, with the G allele showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.71 and a p-value of 5.05×10^-23. This association was consistent across multiple ancestries, with replication studies showing a combined OR of 1.65 and significant p-values, indicating a strong link to DME.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS analysis identifies two novel loci associated with diabetic eye disease and highlights APOL1 as a high risk locus in patients with diabetic macular edema

finding: The SNP rs5030613, found in the intronic region of the DERL3 gene (chromosome 22q11.23), was associated with decreased PRU values (β: -33.53, 95% CI: -46.76 to -20.3, p=9.42·10^-7). DERL3 is involved in endoplasmic reticulum degradation processes and has been suggested to possess protective roles for the heart.
title: Discovery of Ancestry-specific Variants Associated with Clopidogrel Response among Caribbean Hispanics

finding: rs4680 was identified as a missense SNP within COMT and was associated with a G to A base change leading to a V to M amino acid change. This change correlated with reduced expression of COMT in PBMCs, consistent with mass-spectrometry results. Its strong association with COMT expression in PBMCs (p = 1.84×10^-27) underscored its relevance in CVD pathology.
title: Dual site proteomic analyses reveal potential drug targets for cardiovascular disease

finding: The SNP rs13268, a missense variant in FBLN1, indicated high significance and was associated with biological pathways relevant to PSA.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The rs738409 SNP, which corresponds to the Ile148Met variant in the PNPLA3 gene, was identified as being associated with hepatic steatosis. This association was evaluated in samples from the QHLI Obesity Biobank, and the genotyping was performed using validated methods. The findings indicated that the presence of this variant was linked with an increased risk of steatosis, thus highlighting its relevance in the context of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
title: Altered branched-chain α-keto acid metabolism is a feature of NAFLD in individuals with severe obesity

finding: This SNP, with a lead signal (p=1.20e-15), mapped to FAM19A5, indicating its role in cannabis use disorder associated with brain-specific gene functions.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: The study observed that tumors harboring BK polyomavirus (BKPyV) exhibited significantly higher average expression of APOBEC3B compared to both normal tissues and tumors that did not contain any virus. Furthermore, this finding was dependent on the germline variant rs1014971, which is known to associate with increased APOBEC3B expression and bladder cancer risk. Specifically, the highest average APOBEC3B expression was recorded in tumors with both BKPyV and two copies of the rs1014971 variant, indicating a potential link between this SNP and the risk of developing virus-associated bladder cancer in solid organ transplant recipients.
title: Evidence for Virus-Mediated Oncogenesis in Bladder Cancers Arising in Solid Organ Transplant Recipients

finding: The rs4819670 variant was identified as the lead <italic>trans</italic>-eQTL variant at the <italic>USP18</italic> locus. This variant's C allele was linked to decreased expression of type I interferon response genes and was associated with an increased risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in East Asians, highlighting its functional relevance in immune regulation.
title: USP18 modulates lupus risk via negative regulation of interferon response

finding: The rs3180408 variant, a missense variant in <italic>USP18</italic>, was in perfect linkage disequilibrium with the SLE lead variant rs4819670. The T allele of rs3180408 was indicated to potentially decrease USP18 function, thus impacting the regulation of type I interferon response genes, which is critical in the context of SLE pathogenesis.
title: USP18 modulates lupus risk via negative regulation of interferon response

finding: The rs738408 variant in the PNPLA3 gene was identified, which is linked to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, reflecting its cardiovascular risk relevance.
title: Discovery and systematic characterization of risk variants and genes for coronary artery disease in over a million participants

finding: The rs129415 variant, correlated with SCUBE1, indicated a role in protecting against thrombosis, supporting its relevance in CAD.
title: Discovery and systematic characterization of risk variants and genes for coronary artery disease in over a million participants

finding: SNP rs229527, located at 22:37,185,445:C:A, was associated with all types of hypothyroidism phenotypes, and its presence was linked to an increased risk for various autoimmune diseases.
title: The Etiology of Hypothyroidism Is Revealed by Alternative Genetics Association Study Methodologies

finding: Similar to rs229527, the SNP rs229526 at 22:37,185,382:G:C was associated with hypothyroidism phenotypes and rising risk factors for multiple autoimmune conditions.
title: The Etiology of Hypothyroidism Is Revealed by Alternative Genetics Association Study Methodologies

finding: The CYP2D6 variant rs769258 was characterized fully using TaqMan DME Genotyping Assays, achieving 100% concordance with benchmark methods, highlighting its reliability in genotyping studies.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 rs267608319 variant was also genotyped with TaqMan DME Genotyping Assays, resulting in a 100% concordance rate to benchmark methods, indicating its significance in pharmacogenetic testing.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 variant rs1065852 achieved a high call rate in the Nala PGx Core study, although there were discrepancies compared to benchmarks, highlighting its relevance in pharmacogenomics.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 rs3892097 variant was part of a larger analysis where Nala PGx Core demonstrated high reliability, but found higher call rates in benchmark platforms indicating its previous documentation as a relevant SNP.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The variant rs5030865 was included in the analysis of CYP2D6 and demonstrated robust data with respect to genotyping, aligning with expected rates in previous literature.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 rs5030655 variant exhibited high reliability in genotyping, further supporting the pharmacogenomic findings of the Nala PGx Core.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The rs35742686 variant within CYP2D6 showed robust genotype outcomes in the Nala PGx Core analysis, aligning well with known pharmacogenetic responses.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 rs28371725 variant was characterized in the study, showcasing reliable results that correlated with established pharmacogenomic data.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The rs5030656 variant in CYP2D6 was included in the analysis, confirming its association with pharmacogenetic implications as seen in previous studies.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 variant rs59421388 returned favorable validation outcomes in relation to drug metabolism and pharmacogenomics as per the findings from Nala PGx Core.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The CYP2D6 rs16947 variant was scrutinized in the study, contributing valuable insights into pharmacogenetic applications thanks to its high reliability scores.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The rs1135840 variant in CYP2D6 was noted for its relevance, showing strong performance in the Nala PGx Core assessment in context with pharmacogenomics.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The SNP rs7292124, located near the ISX gene, was identified as significantly associated with tau deposition, with a p-value of 2.20×10^-8, confirming its potential role in tau pathology in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Genome-wide scan of Flortaucipir PET levels finds JARID2 associated with cerebral tau deposition

finding: The SNP rs66812091 was associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), exhibiting a recessive relationship with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.3 and a highly significant p-value of 2×10^-12. This finding was notably more significant compared to the additive model, which showed a p-value of 2×10^-11. Additionally, the dominance deviation p-value was significant at 3×10^-2. The association with NAFLD highlighted the gene PNPLA3's involvement in lipid and fatty acid metabolism.
title: Widespread recessive effects on common diseases in a cohort of 44,000 British Pakistanis and Bangladeshis with high autozygosity

finding: This SNP synonymously refers to rs66812091 and thus shares the same association with NAFLD. It was linked to a recessive model of inheritance that suggested it might have been previously overlooked in studies utilizing an additive framework.
title: Widespread recessive effects on common diseases in a cohort of 44,000 British Pakistanis and Bangladeshis with high autozygosity

finding: The missense variant rs738409 in PNPLA3 was correlated with 0.27 attributable DALYs in males and 0.05 in females related to liver disease, revealing notable sex differences in disease burden.
title: Genetic risk factors have a substantial impact on healthy life years

finding: The SNP rs738409 in the gene PNPLA3 was identified as a significant genetic variant affecting the risk of liver disease, particularly non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), thereby linking it to impaired glucagon signaling in hepatocytes.
title: Studies to develop a glucagon sensitivity test in humans: The GLUSENTIC study protocol

finding: The rs6971 SNP, associated with TSPO, revealed significant group differences in binding affinity across various cohorts, specifically showing a classification into low, medium, or high affinity binders (LAB, MAB, or HAB). The analysis indicated that individuals with different TSPO SNP statuses exhibited considerable variations in microglial activation and related clinical performances. Notably, a significant group difference was identified in the rs6971 SNP status among patients with 4RT, AD-CBS, typical AD, and healthy controls (χ² = 8.575, p = 0.036), highlighting its relevance in the context of AD and its primary tauopathies.
title: Individual regional associations between Aβ-, tau- and neurodegeneration (ATN) with microglial activation in patients with primary and secondary tauopathies

finding: The SNP rs73885319, associated with the G1 variant of the APOL1 gene, was linked to an increased risk of sepsis (OR=1.29; 95% CI, 1.00–1.67; p=0.047) among Black patients with infections. However, this association was not significant after adjusting for severe renal disease.
title: Association between APOL1 risk variants and progression from infection to sepsis

finding: The SNP rs60910145, also related to the G1 variant of APOL1, exhibited similar results as rs73885319. It was part of the high-risk genotypes that conferred increased susceptibility to sepsis in the cohort of Black patients, but adjustments for pre-existing renal issues nullified this increased risk.
title: Association between APOL1 risk variants and progression from infection to sepsis

finding: The SNP rs71785313, corresponding to the G2 variant of the APOL1 gene, contributed to the high-risk genotypes associated with sepsis. Like the other two SNPs, the association was attenuated upon adjusting for severe renal disease.
title: Association between APOL1 risk variants and progression from infection to sepsis

finding: The SNP rs12106505 served as a proxy for the G2 allele (rs71785313) and was implicated in the risk of sepsis among Black patients with infections, yet the increased risk was primarily attributed to pre-existing renal disease, as observed for other APOL1 variants.
title: Association between APOL1 risk variants and progression from infection to sepsis

finding: The SNP rs5748614, near XKR3, achieved study-wide significance within a non-cognitive category.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The SNP rs9608356, located near KIAA1671, was included among the six SNPs that retained study significance in non-cognitive measures.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The SNP rs35823862 intronic to EP300 maintained significance associated with neuroprotective effects in later AD stage endophenotypes.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The variant rs555607708 in the CHEK2 gene was positively associated with the risk of developing at least two primary cancers, with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.72. This variant was particularly common among individuals with breast, prostate, melanoma, or cervical cancers.
title: Assessment of Genetic Susceptibility to Multiple Primary Cancers through Whole-Exome Sequencing in Two Large Multi-Ancestry Studies

finding: This non-frameshift INDEL was found in exon 11 of BAIAP2L2 at 22q13.1, predicted to affect protein structure. It was also an eQTL for nine genes including <SLC16A8> and <TRIOBP>, linking the variant to age-related macular degeneration and cancer cell motility.
title: Genome-wide analysis of brain age identifies 25 associated loci and unveils relationships with mental and physical health

finding: The genetic risk variant PNPLA3 (I148M) rs738409 was evaluated for its predictive impact on metabolic HCC in a subgroup of participants with available genetic data. A model including demographic and clinical variables along with rs738409 had a validation AUC of 0.66, sensitivity of 0.80, and specificity of 0.45. Further, when combined with 55 differentially methylated CpGs, the model yielded a validation AUC of 0.75, sensitivity of 0.74, and specificity of 0.70, indicating that this variant contributed to improved model performance in predicting metabolic HCC.
title: Genome-wide DNA methylation markers associated with metabolic liver cancer

finding: The PNPLA3 rs738409 genotype was validated as a major genetic risk factor for MASLD, with significant association found in the dataset based on fibroscan evaluated liver fibrosis. The glm adjusted p-value for the association was 0.028, supporting its role in liver disease severity.
title: Mycobiome Dysbiosis and Genetic Predisposition for Elevated IL-17A Drive Fibrosis in MASLD

finding: The variant rs7287124 was identified as a lead eQTL variant for XBP1 expression in pancreatic islets. It was significantly associated with lower beta-cell function and higher stimulated glucose in a cohort of 470 South Asian Indians with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes. The study reported a per allele effect on HbA1c of 4.32 mmol/mol (P=8×10^-7) and a stronger effect of 6.41 mmol/mol in individuals diagnosed young with non-obese BMI (P=2×10^-4). The variant was associated with impaired response to sulphonylureas.
title: XBP1 expression in pancreatic islet cells is associated with poor glycaemic control across ancestries especially in young non-obese onset diabetes

finding: The SNP rs773404017 related to ADSL was associated with N6-succinyladenosine, implicating its role in nucleotide metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The SNP rs182488695 in SEC14L2 was positively correlated with gamma-tocopherol/beta-tocopherol levels, suggesting its role in vitamin E metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The rs2285097 SNP, which causes the mEH Tyr61Ser polymorphism, was associated with altered activity of the microsomal epoxide hydrolase (mEH) enzyme. This alteration in activity has implications for the metabolism of propylene oxide (PO) within the human body, potentially leading to increased susceptibility to certain cancers due to inadequate detoxification of epoxides. The finding highlighted the genetic influence on individual variability in detoxification processes related to PO, underscoring the importance of genetic factors in environmental health.
title: Biological Factors Influencing Individual Responses to Propylene Oxide: A Systematic Review of Exogenous Exposure, Endogenous Production and Detoxification

finding: The SNP rs142795512 was also significantly associated with pregnancy loss, presenting an odds ratio (OR) of 4.72 and a P-value of 9.64×10^-9. This variant is an intronic variant in the TRMU gene, which encodes a mitochondrial tRNA-modifying enzyme that has been linked to multiple disease phenotypes.
title: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes in Nulliparas

finding: The SNP rs114058457 was identified as a significant SNP in the GWAS for pregnancy loss and was previously established as an eQTL for the TTC38 gene, implicating it in the regulation of gene expression related to this phenotype.
title: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes in Nulliparas

finding: The SNP rs873492, located within the MIRLET7BHG region, was significantly associated with endometriosis, with a p-value of 4.80E-08. This locus was one of the seven previously unreported findings in the analysis.
title: Expanding the genetic landscape of endometriosis: Integrative -omics analyses uncover key pathways from a multi-ancestry study of over 900,000 women

finding: The SNP rs131529 was assessed as having a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.32 and was in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with 348 other SNPs with an R² value of 0.15 or greater. This SNP was included in the analysis of genetic variance for multiple complex traits.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: The SNP rs2096537 had a MAF of 0.14 and was in LD with 295 other SNPs (R² ≥ 0.15). Its contribution to the genetic variance was evaluated, linking it to the traits analyzed in the study.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: rs131538 exhibited a MAF of 0.05 and had LD with 82 other SNPs (R² ≥ 0.15). This SNP's role in genetic variance concerning the researched traits was investigated.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: The SNP rs141962840 had a low MAF of 0.007 and was in LD with 11 other SNPs with R² ≥ 0.15. Its effect was evaluated as part of the complex traits assessment.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: With a MAF of 0.02, rs117873986 had LD with 12 other SNPs (R² ≥ 0.15). This SNP was included as a part of the genetic determinants analyzed for the complex traits.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: Having a MAF of 0.005 and being in LD with 1 other SNP (R² ≥ 0.15), rs9606483 was part of the study's assessment of variants contributing to genetic variance.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: The SNP rs78881648 had a MAF of 0.009 and was in LD with 1 other SNP (R² ≥ 0.15). It was included in the analysis for potential contributions to the traits being studied.
title: Probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture underlying functional enrichment of complex traits

finding: The index variant rs2267161 in the <italic>GAL3ST1</italic> locus was a common missense variant (p.Met29Val) and prioritized as a tier 1 risk gene. It showed strong associations with elevated sulfatide blood lipid levels and the sCJD risk allele, indicating a significant role in lipid metabolism related to sCJD risks.
title: Multiomic Analyses Direct Hypotheses for Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease Risk Genes

finding: The SNP rs760294168, a homozygous variant in the MCAT gene causing the amino acid change p.T271I, was identified in a proband with combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency. This variant conformed to autosomal recessive inheritance, being heterozygous in both parents. The variant was associated with severe clinical symptoms including hypotonia, failure to thrive, and abnormal brain MRI findings. Its high CADD score of 28.9 suggested it was damaging, further supported by SIFT and PolyPhen-2 predictions.
title: Recessive pathogenic variants in MCAT cause combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency

finding: The SNP rs738409 located in the PNPLA3 gene was associated with increased severity of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This variant was recognized for altering triglyceride hydrolysis, thereby impacting liver metabolism and contributing to the progression of NAFLD.
title: Quantitative genome-scale analysis of human liver reveals dysregulation of glycosphingolipid pathways in progressive nonalcoholic fatty liver disease

finding: The rs5751191 SNP on chromosome 22 was identified as the top independent genome-wide significant locus for cognitive function (P=2.02×10^-12) and overlapped with the NDUFA6 gene. This SNP showed significant associations with educational attainment in the context of the PTV burden analysis, highlighting its relevance in cognitive function variance.
title: The impact of rare protein coding genetic variation on adult cognitive function

finding: The rs6001566 variant acted as a sentinel eQTL for the MGAT3 gene and contributed to transferrin glycosylation through significant associations that persisted after conditioning on this variant.
title: Exome sequencing reveals aggregates of rare variants in glycosyltransferase and other genes influencing immunoglobulin G and transferrin glycosylation

finding: The variant rs7289446 was identified as the top signal associated with continuous l-ARMSS severity analysis, demonstrating a beta of -0.4882 (p=2.73×10^-7). It was intronic to SEZ6L, a gene linked to dendritic spine density and arborization, and was also predictive of time to irreversible EDSS scores, with adjusted hazard ratios of 0.77 for irEDSS3 (p=0.008) and 0.72 for irEDSS6 (p=4.85×10^-4).
title: Not all roads lead to the immune system: The Genetic Basis of Multiple Sclerosis Severity Implicates Central Nervous System and Mitochondrial Involvement

finding: The variant rs1207401, which was also intronic to SEZ6L, was implicated in the continuous l-MSSS severity analysis, showing a beta of -0.4841 (p=2.88×10^-7). It was in perfect linkage disequilibrium with rs7289446.
title: Not all roads lead to the immune system: The Genetic Basis of Multiple Sclerosis Severity Implicates Central Nervous System and Mitochondrial Involvement

finding: The rs139911 SNP located at 22q13.1 highlighted shared genetic influences in sleep and cardiac structures.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs763121 was found in the 3' UTR of DDX17, a gene encoding DEAD-box helicase 17. This SNP was associated with breast cancer and emphasizes the significance of APA-linked genetic variants in cancer susceptibility.
title: A distinct class of pan-cancer susceptibility genes revealed by alternative polyadenylation transcriptome-wide association study

finding: The SNP rs41260844 was identified as being associated with congenital heart disease (CHD). The minor allele of this SNP was significantly enriched in CHD patients compared to healthy controls, indicating a higher risk of CHD (p = 0.0041, OR = 1.42, 95% CI = 1.11-1.81). Functional studies showed that the minor allele increased TBX1 promoter activity and reduced the promoter's binding affinity with nuclear proteins, suggesting a crucial role in the pathogenesis of CHD.
title: Upregulation of TBX1 by genetic variants are associated with human congenital heart disease

finding: SNP rs41298814 was found to be a risk factor for CHD occurrence, noted for its associations in haplotype analyses where it contributed to a haplotype with an increased risk of CHD (p = 0.0049, OR = 2.38, 95% CI = 1.01-5.65). This finding identifies it as a significant risk factor alongside being part of a linkage disequilibrium with other SNPs.
title: Upregulation of TBX1 by genetic variants are associated with human congenital heart disease

finding: The analysis revealed that the rs6971 SNP affected TSPO binding affinity, with participants classified as high affinity binders (HAB) comprising 55% of the cohort, mixed affinity binders (MAB) 32%, and low affinity binders (LAB) 13%. This distribution corroborated known frequencies and indicated that the polymorphism influenced the efficacy of TSPO PET imaging in measuring inflammatory changes in ADRD.
title: Alzheimer’s-associated inflammatory alterations mediate tau-associated neurodegeneration in limbic and temporal regions across clinical variants of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The G allele of rs738409 in the PNPLA3 locus was associated with increased levels of various triglycerides, including TG(57:10), TG(46:0), and TG(56:6) in the PROMIS population. This non-synonymous variant, known for its link to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), affected lipid metabolism and demonstrated significant differences in lipid levels determined by genotype.
title: Genome-wide analysis of blood lipid metabolites in over 5,000 South Asians reveals biological insights at cardiometabolic disease loci

finding: Associations were established for the intronic variant rs12484809 within the PNPLA3 locus with triglycerides TG(56:6) and TG(56:5). This finding provided deeper insights into the specific triglycerides impacted by alterations at the PNPLA3 gene, enhancing prior knowledge of lipid dynamics linked to cardiovascular health.
title: Genome-wide analysis of blood lipid metabolites in over 5,000 South Asians reveals biological insights at cardiometabolic disease loci

finding: The missense variant rs2267161 in the GAL3ST1 locus was associated with PG(32:1). This finding enhanced the understanding of GAL3ST1's role in modulating lipid homeostasis and its potential influence on neurological and metabolic diseases.
title: Genome-wide analysis of blood lipid metabolites in over 5,000 South Asians reveals biological insights at cardiometabolic disease loci

finding: SNP rs2413450 was associated with the 'Hemochromatosis Brain' with a p-value of 2.52×10^-50, and is located in the TMPRSS6 gene, which is involved in the production signaling pathway of hepcidin, a key regulator of iron absorption in humans.
title: Polygenic architecture of a novel MRI endophenotype: the “hemochromatosis brain”

finding: The SNP rs855791 was associated with TMPRSS6, another gene involved in iron homeostasis. This finding reinforced the connection between iron regulation and myocardial interstitial fibrosis.
title: Genetics of Myocardial Interstitial Fibrosis in the Human Heart and Association with Disease

finding: The G allele of rs738409 was significantly associated with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and reduced estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) in the UK Biobank dataset. This association was maintained even after adjusting for major metabolic disorders. The findings suggested a causal relationship where genetically predisposed individuals for NAFLD had worse kidney function. This was further supported by summary-level Mendelian randomization (MR) using the CKDGen dataset, reinforcing the idea that NAFLD causally reduced kidney function.
title: Causal effects from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease on kidney function: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The variant rs369250 located in THAP7 showed suggestive association with diabetic kidney disease (DKD) with a p-value of 1.50×10^-5 and was replicated in the FinnGen dataset for chronic kidney disease (CKD) and DKD phenotypes.
title: Whole-exome and Whole-genome Sequencing of 1097 Individuals with Type 1 Diabetes Reveals Novel Genes for Diabetic Kidney Disease

finding: The SNP rs555607708 was identified as a significant frameshift variant in CHEK2 associated with later menopause timing, with a p-value of 1.6 x 10^-27, noted for its relevance in breast cancer.
title: Rare coding variants in five DNA damage repair genes associate with timing of natural menopause

finding: A second significant frameshift variant at CHEK2, rs587780174, was associated with later menopause, showing a substantial p-value of 1.7 x 10^-9.
title: Rare coding variants in five DNA damage repair genes associate with timing of natural menopause

finding: The SNP rs12628403 was identified as a proxy for a germline deletion in the APOBEC3 region, which was detected in 148 out of 552 ESCC cases, constituting 27% of cases. This deletion was associated with decreased total APOBEC mutation burden, specifically with COSMIC signatures SBS2 and SBS13, and was present in lower frequencies in ESCC from China and Japan compared to the expected frequencies in the general East Asian population, suggesting a potential protective role in ESCC.
title: Mutational signatures in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma from eight countries of varying incidence

finding: The SNP rs9610955 replicated the association with FEV1 in the study with a p-value of 1.0×10^-4 and a beta estimate of -0.38, indicating consistent direction of effect across the studies.
title: Multi-omic association study implicates PPP1R13B in DNA methylation-mediated genotype and smoking exposure effects on lung function in children living in urban settings

finding: The SNP rs11090045, also related to the gene CHADL, was associated with neuroticism, showcasing its potential relevance in the context of personality traits and certain psychiatric conditions.
title: An oligogenic risk-model for Gilles de la Tourette syndrome based on whole-genome sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs36062310 was discovered as a missense variant in the gene KLHDC7B, which had been uncharacterized in the context of hearing loss. Its identification with a significant odds ratio of 2.14 suggested its potential role in hearing loss.
title: Population-scale analysis of common and rare genetic variation associated with hearing loss in adults

finding: The SNP rs855791 in TMPRSS6 was positively associated with increased manganese levels and with other anemias, indicating a possible role in iron metabolism.
title: New insights into the genetic etiology of 57 essential and non-essential trace elements in humans

finding: The rs555607708 variant, identified as a loss-of-function (pLOF) variant in the CHEK2 gene, was associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Women carrying this pLOF variant had a hazard ratio of 3.4 (95% CI: 2.4-4.8) for developing breast cancer, indicating a significant relationship between the variant and high-risk status.
title: Combining rare and common genetic variants improves population risk stratification for breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs855791 was associated with iron metabolism and oral iron absorption, specifically highlighted in a study involving Taiwanese women. This variant was considered pathogenic as it was part of the analysis that contributed to the understanding of iron deficiency anaemia, notably IRIDA, wherein it affected the iron absorption capacity.
title: The global prevalence and ethnic heterogeneity of iron-refractory iron deficiency anaemia

finding: The MYH9 rs11089788 C>A polymorphism was associated with kidney allograft outcomes in recipients. Specifically, recipients with the AA-genotype had a significantly elevated risk of delayed graft function (DGF) and biopsy-proven acute rejection (BPAR), although significance was lost after adjusting for confounders. Importantly, the combined presence of the MYH9 polymorphism in donor-recipient pairs showed a significant association with long-term kidney allograft survival, with a hazard ratio of 1.68 after adjustment for potential confounders.
title: A non-muscle myosin heavy chain 9 genetic variant is associated with graft failure following kidney transplantation

finding: The SNP rs2284084 also emerged as significant in the meta-analysis for rare neurodevelopmental conditions, achieving a p-value of 1.7x10^-8. This variant was part of a locus associated with cognitive traits, supporting its role in the polygenic risk for neurodevelopmental conditions.
title: Dissecting the contribution of common variants to risk of rare neurodevelopmental conditions

finding: The lead SNP, rs2294915, located within the 22q13.31 locus, was linked to various liver-related phenotypes in the Admixed American (AMR) population during the phenome-wide association study. This intronic variant in the PNPLA3 gene showed a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.45 in the AMR group and was associated with increased risk for chronic nonalcoholic liver disease.
title: Leveraging genomic diversity for discovery in an EHR-linked biobank: the UCLA ATLAS Community Health Initiative

finding: Although not directly tested due to quality control filtering, rs738409, a missense variant in the PNPLA3 gene, was mentioned as being closely linked to rs2294915 with a high linkage disequilibrium (LD) in both the AMR and European (EUR) populations. This variant has been well-documented in its association with susceptibility to various liver diseases, contributing to the findings related to liver disease in both ethnic groups.
title: Leveraging genomic diversity for discovery in an EHR-linked biobank: the UCLA ATLAS Community Health Initiative

finding: The rs917864 variant located in the 5' untranslated region of IL17RA was newly identified as a susceptibility variant for psoriasis, associated with an odds ratio of 1.08 and a p-value of 3.9×10^-9, underlining its potential role in therapeutic targeting.
title: GWAS meta-analysis of psoriasis identifies new susceptibility alleles impacting disease mechanisms and therapeutic targets

finding: Similar to rs281287, SNP rs202665 was included in the 42 SNPs connected to the common liability to addiction and mapped near relevant genes, indicating relevance in the context of addiction.
title: Novel insights into the common heritable liability to addiction: a multivariate genome-wide association study

finding: The COMT SNP-165599 showed moderate association with changes in PANSS negative scores in African Americans treated with risperidone.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: This SNP was the most significant eQTL for the MCHR1 gene in excitatory neurons, which was also identified in the BIP GWAS. Evidence indicated that it may correspond to a neuron-specific enhancer involved in mood regulation and circadian rhythm disruption.
title: A unified framework for cell-type-specific eQTLs prioritization by integrating bulk and scRNA-seq data

finding: The rs17683430 SNP demonstrated a supported role for SGLT1 inhibition as a potential therapeutic option in gout.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: The SNP rs132131 was mentioned as associated with high tumor dedifferentiation, solidifying its relevance as a CRC risk factor.
title: Colorectal Cancer Risk and Ancestry in Colombian admixed Populations

finding: The rs555607708 variant, c.1100del in CHEK2, was associated with a moderate risk of breast and prostate cancer and was noted to reflect a rare occurrence within the Northern Isles due to genetic drift.
title: Two founder variants account for over 90% of pathogenic BRCA alleles in Orkney and Shetland

finding: The frameshift mutation c.1100delC in CHEK2 (rs555607708) was associated with early-onset infertility and previously linked to an increased risk for breast and ovarian cancer as well as leiomyoma, thyroid cancer, and myeloproliferative disorders. Additionally, a recent study noted its association with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), exhibiting an OR of 13.46 (p = 1.68×10^-9).
title: Inherited infertility - mapping loci associated with impaired female reproduction

finding: The rs738409-G allele in PNPLA3 showed significant associations with chronic nonalcoholic liver disease and cirrhosis in the PheWAS of European American and Hispanic American individuals. Additionally, rs738409-G was linked to abnormal results in liver function studies in the Hispanic American cohort. The data presented conflicting interpretations regarding its impact on COVID-19 severity.
title: A comprehensive knowledgebase of known and predicted human genetic variants associated with COVID-19 susceptibility and severity

finding: The SNP rs117674301 was classified as a cis-pQTL in the context of the APOL1 polygenic risk score, which was statistically significantly associated with giant cell arteritis (GCA) susceptibility, revealing that increasing levels of APOL1 was linked to a reduced risk of GCA.
title: Exploration of the circulating human secretome through protein quantitative trait analysis identifies an association between circulating levels of apolipoprotein L1 and risk of giant cell arteritis

finding: The SNP rs117850190 was also identified as a cis-pQTL within the APOL1 PRS, which significantly correlated with GCA susceptibility, indicating that higher APOL1 levels could confer a protective effect against GCA.
title: Exploration of the circulating human secretome through protein quantitative trait analysis identifies an association between circulating levels of apolipoprotein L1 and risk of giant cell arteritis

finding: The SNP rs73166864 was associated with COVID-19 susceptibility, achieving genome-wide significance with a P-value of 1.56×10^-8 and an OR of 1.70. This SNP was located near the immunoglobulin lambda locus, which plays a role in antibody production, indicating that it may also contribute to variability in disease responses.
title: AncestryDNA COVID-19 Host Genetic Study Identifies Three Novel Loci

finding: The SNP rs73885319 was part of the G1 high-risk allele, characterized by the presence of the missense variant p.S342G. This finding was significant as it contributed to the classification of individuals with high-risk APOL1 genotypes, which were linked to a lifetime risk of kidney failure.
title: Prevalence of Mendelian kidney disease among patients with high-risk APOL1 genotypes undergoing commercial genetic testing in the United States

finding: The SNP rs60910145 was associated with the G1 high-risk allele, marked by the missense variant p.I384M. This allele was crucially involved in defining high-risk APOL1 genotypes, correlating with the observed lifetime risk of developing progressive kidney disease in affected individuals.
title: Prevalence of Mendelian kidney disease among patients with high-risk APOL1 genotypes undergoing commercial genetic testing in the United States

finding: The SNP rs71785313 was part of the G2 high-risk allele, characterized by an in-frame deletion at codons 388 and 389. This allele was significant in identifying high-risk APOL1 genotypes and contributed to the understanding of the predisposition to kidney disease among individuals carrying these variants.
title: Prevalence of Mendelian kidney disease among patients with high-risk APOL1 genotypes undergoing commercial genetic testing in the United States

finding: The SNP rs134041 was identified as having a significant association with lung function, supported by a p-value of 1 × 10^-27, indicating its potential relevance in respiratory health and disease.
title: Unraveling COVID-19 Relationship with Anxiety Disorders and Symptoms

finding: The SNP rs134016 showed a strong association with brain-imaging phenotypes, with a p-value of 8 × 10^-19, suggestive of its influence on brain structure and function.
title: Unraveling COVID-19 Relationship with Anxiety Disorders and Symptoms

finding: The study identified rs6006426 as a novel susceptibility locus for pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB) at 22q12.2, showing a significant association with PTB across various East Asian datasets, with a meta-analysis P-value of 3.31×10^-10. Notably, the A allele of rs6006426 was linked to reduced expression of the gene SF3A1 in immune-related cells, suggesting a potential mechanism for increased susceptibility to TB.
title: Common variants at 22q12.2 are associated with susceptibility to Tuberculosis

finding: The SNP rs7290267 near FLJ27365 was significantly associated with FEV1, with a P-value of 1.49x10^-9 and a beta of -0.0272, indicating its novel relevance to lung function.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: The SNP rs62227770 was recognized for its significant association with DED in hot spring residents, denoting an important GxE interaction.
title: Hot Spring Residency and Disease Association: a Crossover Gene-Environment Interaction (GxE) Study in Taiwan

finding: Identified as a novel intronic variant located near the CHEK2 gene, this variant demonstrated a genome-wide significance at p=9.69 x 10^-11. It was in complete linkage disequilibrium with the frameshift variant c.1100delC, which was also enriched in the Finnish population.
title: Circulating anti-Müllerian hormone levels in pre-menopausal women: novel genetic insights from a GWAS meta-analysis

finding: rs1473811, the fourth novel SNP linked to externalizing traits, demonstrated associations with chronotype, schizophrenia, and social support.
title: A Multivariate Genome-Wide Association Study Reveals Neural Correlates and Common Biological Mechanisms of Psychopathology Spectra

finding: The lead SNP rs62228062 was identified as genome-wide significant for frozen shoulder during a study involving the UK Biobank and was replicated in the FinnGen study. The odds ratio for this SNP was 1.34 in the UK Biobank, indicating an increased risk associated with the G allele. Additionally, rs62228062 was strongly associated with Dupuytren's contracture, with an odds ratio of 2.61. The evidence suggested a potential causal role of the gene WNT7B in this condition.
title: A genome wide association study of frozen shoulder identifies a common variant of WNT7B and diabetes as causal risk factors

finding: The SNP rs112809886 was significantly associated with progression to Hoehn and Yahr stage 3 or greater (p=1.9×10^-9). This variant was shown to be associated with increased ADORA2A expression, suggesting a role in motor progression.
title: Genome-wide determinants of mortality and clinical progression in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs5758550, located in the enhancer region over 100 kb downstream of the CYP2D6 gene, had been found to substantially increase CYP2D6 transcription. This finding highlighted the significance of enhancer SNPs in modulating CYP2D6 activity, particularly in conjunction with other SNPs.
title: The potential of CYP2D6 phenotyping to improve opioid dosing strategies

finding: The SNP rs133333, also identified in the enhancer region >100 kb downstream of CYP2D6, was associated with significant alterations in CYP2D6 mRNA expression. It contributed to the increase in CYP2D6 transcription, suggesting its role as a critical regulator of opioid metabolism.
title: The potential of CYP2D6 phenotyping to improve opioid dosing strategies

finding: The SNP rs16947 was noted to reduce CYP2D6 function; however, it was counteracted by enhancer SNPs, indicating its involvement in modulating opioid metabolic processes. Specifically, haplotypes containing rs16947 exhibited altered CYP2D6 metabolic activity which was significantly influenced by enhancer SNPs present.
title: The potential of CYP2D6 phenotyping to improve opioid dosing strategies

finding: The RNF215 locus's association revealed a link to vitamin E levels, showcasing its role in vitamin metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The TMPRSS6 locus was established as a genetic association for iron levels, providing insights into iron metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: This SNP, representing the G2 variant, was significantly associated with increased APOL1 protein concentration, reaching genome-wide significance with a p-value of 3×10^-155.
title: APOL1 variants G1, G2 and N264K affect APOL1 plasma protein concentration: a UK Biobank study

finding: The rs228914 variant in the TMPRSS6 gene was identified as a significant locus associated with lower MCH and MCV. It was noted as a cis-eQTL for TMPRSS6 and linked to iron levels.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The rs2413667 SNP was identified as an eQTL for CYP2D6, linking it to the odds of missingness of solanidine. This association underscored its potential as a pharmacogenomic marker for identifying individuals with differing metabolic capabilities regarding various xenobiotics.
title: Genome-wide Association Studies of Missing Metabolite Measures: Results From Two Population-based Studies

finding: The SNP rs3761472-G in the SAMM50 gene was associated with higher risk for fatty liver disease (FLD) in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS), showing an odds ratio (OR) of 2.9 (2.0-4.1; p=0.002). This association was significant among Group4 (FLD+/MetS+), indicating a correlation with severe disease phenotype.
title: Severe liver damage, low bone mineral content, and PDXDC1/TTC39B gene variations linked to NAFLD with metabolic syndrome

finding: The SNP rs738409-G located in the PNPLA3 gene was significantly associated with an increased risk of fatty liver disease in patients with metabolic syndrome, with an odds ratio of 2.8 (1.9-4.07; p=0.003). It was among the three previously identified SNPs firmly linked to fatty liver disease pathogenesis.
title: Severe liver damage, low bone mineral content, and PDXDC1/TTC39B gene variations linked to NAFLD with metabolic syndrome

finding: The SNP rs35665085-A in the CECR5 gene was associated with an increased risk of fatty liver with metabolic syndrome, evidenced by an odds ratio of 2.7 (1.9-3.9; p=0.038). This SNP represents a missense variation that contributes to the disease phenotype.
title: Severe liver damage, low bone mineral content, and PDXDC1/TTC39B gene variations linked to NAFLD with metabolic syndrome

finding: The SNP rs5757587 was among those significantly associated with the joint IBD-PBC phenotype, emphasizing its relevance in the context of autoimmune disease comorbidity.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The variant rs60910145 in the APOL1 gene was successfully replicated in both European-American and Latin-American cohorts for FSGS association, confirming its significance with a p-value below the threshold, reflecting its risk association across these populations.
title: CR1 variants contribute to FSGS susceptibility across multiple populations

finding: The rs73885319 variant in the APOL1 gene was also identified as significantly associated with FSGS in the European-American cohort and was successfully replicated in the Latin-American cohort, with significant p-values demonstrating its importance in FSGS pathology.
title: CR1 variants contribute to FSGS susceptibility across multiple populations

finding: The T allele of lead variant rs62237617 at 22q12.1-CHEK2 conferred a significant risk for DNMT3A mutation-associated CH, suggesting a pronounced impact of rare variants in the context of clonal hematopoiesis.
title: Genome-wide analyses of 200,453 individuals yields new insights into the causes and consequences of clonal hematopoiesis

finding: This rare TTC28 variant rs186184919 on 22q12.1 was shown to be associated with squamous cell carcinoma risk.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The missense variant rs73885319 in the APOL1 gene was replicated in associations related to kidney-related conditions, including end-stage renal disease, particularly noted in African populations.
title: Diversity and Scale: Genetic Architecture of 2,068 Traits in the VA Million Veteran Program

finding: This SNP in an intergenic region on chromosome 22 was identified as a genome-wide significant locus associated with TRD with a P-value of 1.82×10^-8. It was linked to decreased expression of the nearest gene MCHR1 in specific brain regions and whole blood, and showed significant association with a genomic locus related to increased risk of bipolar disorder, suggesting potentially shared genetic factors between TRD and other psychiatric conditions.
title: Genome-wide association study of treatment resistant depression highlights shared biology with metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs111490516 was identified as a novel low-frequency variant associated with body mass index (BMI), particularly common in African and Barbadian populations, with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 13%. It demonstrated significant association with BMI in a diverse study population and was replicated in multiple studies, where it had a MAF ranging from 11% to 13% in African-derived samples.
title: WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING ANALYSIS OF BODY MASS INDEX IDENTIFIES NOVEL AFRICAN ANCESTRY-SPECIFIC RISK ALLELE

finding: The SNP rs11538 was connected to the protein BCL2L13. The analysis demonstrated that a significant proportion of the colocalization probability involving BMI, dietary habits, and protein levels was attributable to this variant.
title: Genetic control of body weight by the human brain proteome

finding: The c.1100delC (rs555607708) variant in CHEK2 was similarly analyzed for its penetrance in breast cancer risk. This analysis was also part of the findings in the aforementioned Finnish population study related to breast cancer.
title: Breast and prostate cancer risk: the interplay of polygenic risk, high-impact monogenic variants, and family history

finding: The SNP rs6006950 was associated with the expression level of NUP50 in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC), with a very significant p-value of 7.5 × 10^-13 indicating that the ALS risk allele (rs6006950-G) was linked to decreased NUP50 expression. This SNP was previously identified in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) related to ALS.
title: Loss of nucleoporin Nup50 is a risk factor for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: This SNP was associated with left ventricular end-systolic volume (LVESV) in both the UK Biobank and Biobank Japan studies, demonstrating its relevance in cardiac structure.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This missense variant in the <italic>TMPRSS6</italic> gene was found to be associated with blood hemoglobin levels and erythrocyte volume.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: Identified as an AMD risk-raising allele, this SNP was significantly associated with retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch’s membrane (RPE+BM) thickening, suggestive of its involvement in drusen development.
title: Photoreceptor layer thinning is an early biomarker for age-related macular degeneration development: Epidemiological and genetic evidence from UK Biobank optical coherence tomography data

finding: This SNP was noted for its significant association with decreased transcription of TIMP3 mRNA, indicating its potential relevance in AMD pathology through its impact on extracellular matrix regulation in retinal tissues.
title: Photoreceptor layer thinning is an early biomarker for age-related macular degeneration development: Epidemiological and genetic evidence from UK Biobank optical coherence tomography data

finding: This SNP overlapped a neuronal enhancer located within the CACNA1I gene body, which is relevant to neuronal excitability and disorders, suggesting its potential involvement in neurological conditions.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: This SNP was associated with an astrocytic enhancer linked to NR1H3, indicating its potential influence on multiple sclerosis (MS) pathology through the regulation of immune response.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: Like rs926334, this SNP also overlapped an enhancer located near NR1H3, reinforcing the genetic association with MS.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs5758064 was mapped to SLC25A17 and was identified as sharing significant genetic associations with both BDI and BDII, supporting the findings of polygenic overlap between the two subtypes.
title: Patterns of convergence and divergence between bipolar disorder type I and type II: evidence from integrative genomic analyses

finding: The SNP rs130406 showed reduced odds of IBS-C with an aOR of 0.68 (95% CI = 0.51-0.91). It was also associated with IBS based on the UKBB data.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: The SNP rs738409 in the PNPLA3 gene was highlighted as a robust association with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), particularly noted for its homozygous G allele variant's high frequency in Hispanic subjects. This association suggests a significant genetic predisposition to NAFLD among Hispanics, relating to more severe conditions including nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), though the specific mechanisms were not fully elucidated in the study.
title: Ethnicity-specific alterations of plasma and hepatic lipidomic profiles are related to high NAFLD rate and severity in Hispanic Americans, a pilot study

finding: The SNP rs555607708, a frameshift variant in CHEK2, was associated with three cancer types: breast cancer (OR 4.15, P = 7.24×10^-25), prostate cancer (OR 2.40, P = 3.48×10^-10), and leukemia (OR 8.48, P = 1.21×10^-9). This significant association indicated a strong link to increased cancer risk.
title: Exome-wide association studies discover germline mutation patterns and identify high-risk populations in human cancers

finding: The SNP rs2277840 was identified as having a previous association with the level of response to alcohol, which is an important endophenotype for alcohol use disorder, and it was also noted in the MOOD and AUD conjunction analysis.
title: Genetic overlap between mood instability and alcohol-related phenotypes suggests shared biological underpinnings

finding: The study noted that the APOL1 G1 variant, represented by rs73885319, was associated specifically with high urinary albumin:creatinine ratio (uACR), illustrating its deleterious effect on kidney health and indicating a distinct pattern of association with chronic kidney disease (CKD) in the examined cohort.
title: Phenome-wide analysis of APOL1 risk variants reveals associations between one combination of haplotypes and multiple disease phenotypes in addition to chronic kidney disease

finding: The APOL1 G2 variant, represented by rs71785313, was implicated in associations with low estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) in the context of CKD. The presence of this variant in compound heterozygosity with G1 specifically led to profound impacts on kidney health, underscoring its deleterious effects.
title: Phenome-wide analysis of APOL1 risk variants reveals associations between one combination of haplotypes and multiple disease phenotypes in addition to chronic kidney disease

finding: The lead cis-sSNP rs34495746 indicated a strong colocalized effect with splicing of IL17RA's transmembrane domain, where 90.41% of the effect on plasma protein levels was mediated via transcript splicing.
title: Genetic determinants of blood gene expression and splicing and their contribution to molecular phenotypes and health outcomes

finding: The SNP rs73885319 represented a missense variant associated with the APOL1 G1 high-risk genotype. This SNP was recognized for its role in increasing the risk of kidney disease, particularly in populations of African American and Hispanic descent.
title: Multi-ethnic polygenic risk modifies the association between APOL1 high risk genotypes and chronic kidney disease

finding: The SNP rs60910145 was also part of the APOL1 G1 high-risk genotype and was described as a missense variant. Its association contributed to the understanding of kidney disease risk across multi-ethnic cohorts.
title: Multi-ethnic polygenic risk modifies the association between APOL1 high risk genotypes and chronic kidney disease

finding: The SNP rs12106505 was utilized as a proxy for the unavailable rs71785313 due to its strong linkage (r² = 0.82). Its presence in individuals defined as having high-risk genotypes (either G1 or G2) was instrumental in assessing the risk of chronic kidney disease.
title: Multi-ethnic polygenic risk modifies the association between APOL1 high risk genotypes and chronic kidney disease

finding: The rs73885319 SNP, associated with the G1 haplotype of the APOL1 gene, was found to contribute to increased odds of COVID-19 hospitalisation and death in individuals with African ancestry. Specifically, individuals with the G1/G2 genotype had a higher odds ratio of 2.1 for hospitalisation and 5.9 for death when compared to the G0/G0 genotype.
title: Adverse outcomes in SARS-CoV-2 infections are associated with a combination of variant genotypes at two loci in the APOL1 gene: a UK Biobank study

finding: The rs71785313 SNP, associated with the G2 haplotype of the APOL1 gene, also contributed to the adverse outcomes of COVID-19. Those with the G1/G2 genotype, which includes this SNP, faced a significantly higher risk of hospitalisation and mortality, reinforcing the finding that these APOL1 high-risk variants increase severe COVID-19 risk in people of African descent.
title: Adverse outcomes in SARS-CoV-2 infections are associated with a combination of variant genotypes at two loci in the APOL1 gene: a UK Biobank study

finding: SNP rs4468, prominent in the AFR population, was substantiated with findings of cardiovascular trait associations thus described as a positive and original finding.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: The SNP rs229527-C in the C1QTNF6 locus was identified and associated with TPOAb levels, highlighting its potential role in the immune regulation of thyroid function.
title: Genome-wide association studies of thyroid-related hormones, dysfunction, and autoimmunity among 85,421 Chinese pregnancies

finding: The study demonstrated that the APOL1 p.N264K missense variant at rs73885316 significantly reduced the toxicity of the G1 and G2 alleles when co-inherited, which effectively lowered the risk associated with high-risk G1G2 and G2G2 genotypes in Black Americans. This finding was pivotal in understanding the mechanisms of APOL1-associated nephropathy, as the presence of this variant provided a protective effect against kidney disease progression.
title: Strong protective effect of the APOL1 p.N264K variant against G2-associated focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and kidney disease

finding: The SNP rs73885319 (also known as G1 allele of APOL1, S342G) was identified as a component of the genetic risk for chronic kidney disease (CKD). Its association was analyzed in conjunction with the polygenic score and demonstrated a strong influence on the risk of developing CKD across various populations, particularly among individuals of African ancestry.
title: Genome-wide polygenic score with APOL1 risk genotypes predicts chronic kidney disease across major continental ancestries

finding: The SNP rs60910145 (1200T>G, also part of the G1 allele of APOL1) contributed to the polygenic score for CKD when combined with data from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). The presence of this variant was linked to increased risk of CKD, supporting its relevance in the genetic architecture of kidney function.
title: Genome-wide polygenic score with APOL1 risk genotypes predicts chronic kidney disease across major continental ancestries

finding: The SNP rs71785313 (1212-del6 variant of the G2 allele of APOL1) was confirmed as part of the risk assessment for CKD. It exhibited an additive effect in conjunction with other polygenic risk factors, enhancing the predictive capability of kidney disease susceptibility among populations of African descent.
title: Genome-wide polygenic score with APOL1 risk genotypes predicts chronic kidney disease across major continental ancestries

finding: The SNP rs855791, which modifies hepcidin levels, was part of the risk score constructed in this analysis. The presence of this SNP among the study participants emphasized the genetic influence on iron metabolism and suggested a pathway by which alcohol intake might exacerbate brain iron deposition.
title: Impact of moderate alcohol consumption on brain iron and cognition: observational and genetic analyses

finding: The SNP rs738409, located in the adiponutrin gene (PNPLA3), was found to be significantly associated with increased white matter hyperintensity (WMH) volume and microbleeds. This association was relevant in the context of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), where the allele contributed to systemic inflammation and vascular injury that might weaken the blood-brain barrier, leading to the development of WMHs. Furthermore, this finding was supported by references to its links with carotid atherosclerosis and the overall understanding of liver-brain interactions.
title: Genetic Interplay Between White Matter Hyperintensities and Alzheimer’s Disease: A Brain-Body Perspective

finding: COMT rs4680 was associated with LNS scores and influenced global and nodal metrics of the functional network in PD patients.
title: Parkinson’s disease-associated genetic variants synergistically shape brain networks

finding: The A allele of rs17000526 in the APOBEC3B region was identified as being associated with higher expression of the APOBEC3B gene, contributing to somatic mutagenesis of APOBEC signatures in bladder tumors.
title: Germline cancer gene expression quantitative trait loci influence local and global tumor mutations

finding: The study included rs1135824 for naive CNV-calls and established a method to assign CNV genotypes based on signal intensity, indicating potential applications for pharmacogenomic (PGx) testing.
title: Low-cost generation of clinical-grade layperson-friendly pharmacogenetic passports using oligonucleotide arrays

finding: Similar to rs1135824, rs1423323203 was also selected for naive CNV-calls. It was part of the methodology that provided a basis for using the GSA-MDv3 with implications in PGx.
title: Low-cost generation of clinical-grade layperson-friendly pharmacogenetic passports using oligonucleotide arrays

finding: The rare intronic variant rs577454702 in MAPK1 was associated with a significantly increased risk of OC, showing an odds ratio of 2.60 (95% CI: 1.86, 3.65, p=2.53×10^-8).
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The SNP rs140522 was prioritized as an enQTL-colocalized event linked with high light scatter reticulocyte count (HLR) and the gene TYMP, which has been previously associated with leukemia.
title: Genetic determinants of gene expression noise and its role in complex trait variation

finding: SNP rs9306356 was an intronic variant in TCF20 identified as novel and associated with AUD.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs5750911, associated with SMK traits, was discovered to be a novel GWS variant within TNRC6B.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: The COMT-Val158Met polymorphism was associated with postpartum depression (PPD) symptoms at 6 weeks postpartum, although this association did not persist at 6 months. This finding suggested a potential role of the COMT variant in influencing the experience of perinatal depression.
title: A sum of its parts: A systematic review evaluating biopsychosocial and behavioral determinants of perinatal depression

finding: The rs6971 SNP (Ala/Thr) in the TSPO gene was identified to affect the binding affinity of the [18F]GE-180 TSPO ligand in positron emission tomography (PET) analysis. Specifically, high-affinity binders (HAB), corresponding to Ala/Ala carriers, were included in the imaging analyses, revealing that microglial activation, as indicated by increased TSPO PET tracer uptake, was linked to cognitive impairment in Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients.
title: MRI connectivity-based spread of microglial activation in early Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The variant rs145598156 was identified as genome-wide significant in the context of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) with a p-value of 3.6 x 10<sup>-8</sup> and an odds ratio (OR) of 3.01 [2.02-4.50]. It was associated with higher risks of PCOS in both Finnish and Estonian populations, showing tight linkage to the c.1100delC deletion variant in CHEK2, which is a known risk factor for several cancer types.
title: Leveraging Northern European population history; novel low frequency variants for polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: The lead variant rs182075939 had a p-value of 1.9 x 10<sup>-16</sup> with an OR of 1.69 [1.49-1.91], indicating a significant association with PCOS risk, primarily in the Estonian population. This variant was located 22 kb from the transcription start site of TTC28 and was associated with the missense I157T variant in CHEK2, further supporting the genetic linkage of CHEK2 to PCOS.
title: Leveraging Northern European population history; novel low frequency variants for polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: The variant rs555607708 (c.1100delC) was associated with heightened PCOS risk and identified as a frameshift variant in CHEK2. It exhibited significant enrichment in the Finnish population, and its high linkage with rs145598156 indicated its pivotal role in the genetic landscape of PCOS.
title: Leveraging Northern European population history; novel low frequency variants for polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: The variant rs112424815 was significant in the context of eQTL analysis, indicating a possible regulatory effect on KTN1 mRNA expression levels in the putamen. This association contributes valuable information about the gene's expression but did not link to PD risk.
title: A genetic and transcriptomic assessment of the KTN1 gene in Parkinson’s disease risk

finding: The SNP rs738409 in the PNPLA3 locus interacted with BMI, influencing alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels, reinforcing its role as a significant vQTL.
title: Hypothesis-free detection of gene-interaction effects on biomarker concentration in UK Biobank using variance prioritisation

finding: The SNP rs3747207 in the PNPLA3 locus correlated with interactions witnessed in alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) studies.
title: Hypothesis-free detection of gene-interaction effects on biomarker concentration in UK Biobank using variance prioritisation

finding: The synonymous variant rs755163625 had a P-value of 9.2×10^-6 and an OR of 2.37; it was associated with a rare syndrome but indicated potential links to UC.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The rs6971 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) was associated with TSPO radioligand binding affinity, and genotyping for this SNP was conducted prior to PET scans in all subjects. It was found that much of the difference in TSPO binding between control and Parkinson's disease (PD) participants was primarily driven by high affinity binder (HAB) subjects. The MAB (median affinity binder) group, which constituted about 30% of the sample, did not show a significant statistical difference in TSPO binding between control and PD subjects. This highlighted the importance of selecting appropriate ligands for PET imaging that are unaffected by this SNP for effective application in a clinical setting.
title: Brain and systemic inflammation in de novo Parkinson’s disease

finding: In the study, homozygous carriers of the PNPLA3 rs738409 variant were associated with an increased risk of cancer incidence, with a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.27 (1.02-1.58), p = 3.1x10^-2. This association was also confirmed in the GoDARTS cohort after excluding patients with liver cancer, where an HR of 1.26 (1.01-1.58), p = 3.8x10^-2 was reported. Thus, the findings suggested that carrying the rs738409 variant not only increased the susceptibility to metabolic dysfunction-related liver disease (MDLD) but also solidified its role in elevating cancer risk, indicating a potential causal link between NAFLD and cancer.
title: Metabolic Dysfunction Related Liver Disease as a Risk Factor for Cancer

finding: In the GOCAR discovery set, the presence of the G1 allele represented by rs73885319 correlated with an increased risk of death-censored allograft loss (DCAL), with a hazard ratio (HR) of 2.14 (P = 0.006). This association was independent of genetic ancestry and was also evident in the African American/Hispanic recipient subgroup, in which the HR increased to 2.36 (P = 0.003).
title: Recipient APOL1 risk alleles associate with death-censored renal allograft survival and rejection episodes

finding: The G1 allele represented by rs60910145 was similarly associated with an increased risk of death-censored allograft loss (DCAL) and any T cell-mediated rejection (TCMR) events in the GOCAR cohort, supporting the findings associated with the G1 allele. It was observed that this association was also validated in the CTOT cohort.
title: Recipient APOL1 risk alleles associate with death-censored renal allograft survival and rejection episodes

finding: Identified as representing the G2 allele, rs71785313 also correlated with increased risk of death-censored allograft loss (DCAL) in the studied cohorts and was directly genotyped. This finding reinforced the validation of the G2 allele's role in transplant outcomes.
title: Recipient APOL1 risk alleles associate with death-censored renal allograft survival and rejection episodes

finding: The variant rs763236 was observed to be associated with DNA methylation variation and exhibited a frequency of 0.363 in UKB-AFR against 0.011 in UKB-EUR, suggesting its role in population-specific epigenetic regulation.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: The loss-of-function allele rs3892097 (CYP2D6*4) indicated its higher occurrence in European populations, contrastingly rare in African and Asian populations, thereby affecting pharmacokinetics.
title: Diversity and level of evidence evaluation of commercial pharmacogenomic testing for mental health

finding: The rs738409 polymorphism in the PNPLA3 gene was identified as a significant risk factor for the development of Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) among the ethnic Bengali population of West Bengal. The risk 'G' allele exhibited higher frequency among NAFLD cases (37.38%) than in controls (24.5%). The homozygous 'GG' genotype was found in 22% of NAFLD cases compared to just 5% in healthy controls, suggesting a strong association with liver fat accumulation. Additionally, the 'G' allele corresponded with elevated FIB-4 and Controlled Attenuation Parameter (CAP) scores, indicating increased liver disease severity.
title: Association of the rs738409 polymorphism in PNPLA3 with development and severity of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in ethnic Bengali population of West Bengal

finding: The SNP rs147678157 was identified to interact with meat dietary patterns, significantly impacting glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels. This interaction was shown to have a p-value of 5.45×10^-9, although there was a marginal genetic main effect observed.
title: Genome-wide gene-diet interaction analysis in the UK Biobank identifies novel effects on Hemoglobin A1c

finding: The SNP rs140270534 interacted with dried fruit consumption, showing strong evidence of its role in modifying HbA1c levels, although the study noted a need for further investigation into its mechanisms as it lay within a pseudogene.
title: Genome-wide gene-diet interaction analysis in the UK Biobank identifies novel effects on Hemoglobin A1c

finding: The study of the rs738409 variant in the PNPLA3/adiponutrin gene indicated that individuals carrying the G allele had higher levels of AST, ALT, and GGT, and exhibited lower fasting insulin and insulin resistance, which correlated with a reduced risk of LGA births when compared to CC homozygotes.
title: Refining the diagnosis of Gestational Diabetes Mellitus: A systematic review to inform efforts in precision medicine

finding: A frameshift deletion in CHEK2 was associated with risks for myeloproliferative neoplasms and lymphoid leukaemia, supporting its role in multiple malignancies.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: This SNP was recognized in the GWAS analysis as significant for hypertension, contributing to our understanding of genetic influences on HTN.
title: An individualized Bayesian method for estimating genomic variants of hypertension

finding: The SNP rs2232088, which corresponded to a homozygous p.R169W variant in the gene MIEF1, was identified in the discovery cohort of EOPD patients. This variant was potentially deleterious and contributed to the prioritization of MIEF1 as a candidate gene for early-onset Parkinson's disease (EOPD). Further analysis indicated that this variant disrupted the oligomerization state of the MID51 protein, supporting the hypothesis that mitochondrial dysfunction plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease.
title: DEFINING CANDIDATE PARKINSON’S DISEASE GENES THROUGH THE ANALYSIS OF GENOME-WIDE HOMOZYGOSITY

finding: The lead SNP rs62231080 was identified at an intergenic locus on chromosome 22, reaching genome-wide significance with a standardized beta of -0.260 and a p-value of 1.48E-8. This locus was mapped to genes NUP50, FAM18A, and RIBC2, as well as lincRNA genes CTA-217C2.1 and CTA-268H5.14, and was associated with within-individual variability of Body Mass Index (BMI) in Huntington disease patients.
title: Clinical and genetic association studies reveal within-individual variability as an integral part of Huntington disease

finding: The rs387907018 variant was identified as a loss-of-function mutation in TMPRSS6 associated with lower MCH/MCV.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The study identified the genotype of the rs6971 polymorphism in the Translocator Protein (TSPO) gene in two long COVID patients, both of whom were identified as C/C genotypes, indicating they were high affinity binders for the PET tracer [18F]DPA-714.
