This finding was significant as it linked the high binding ability of the PET tracer to the profound neuroinflammation observed in these patients, suggesting a possible role of TSPO genotype in the pathophysiology of long COVID.
title: Long COVID is associated with extensive in-vivo neuroinflammation on [18F]DPA-714 PET

finding: The SNP rs738409 in the PNPLA3 gene was linked to higher MASLD risk among normal weight individuals. Carriers of the GG genotype exhibited the highest risk compared to those with overweight or obesity, indicating its substantial impact on hepatic steatosis regardless of body weight.
title: Potential causal links between genetic variants in SAMM50, SUGP1, MAU2, and GATAD2A and liver fat in individuals with normal weight

finding: The variant rs738408, also located in the PNPLA3 gene, exhibited the most significant association in the QT-GWAS with a p-value of 5.4E-30, reinforcing its prominence as a genetic risk factor for hepatic fat accumulation.
title: Potential causal links between genetic variants in SAMM50, SUGP1, MAU2, and GATAD2A and liver fat in individuals with normal weight

finding: The exonic SNP rs1007863 was found in the 22q13.31 region and demonstrated significant eQTL associations, particularly in visceral adipose tissue related to MAFLD and atrial fibrillation (AF) outcomes. This indicates its potential importance in the shared genetic architecture of MAFLD and cardiovascular diseases.
title: Genome-wide insights into the shared genetic landscape between metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease and cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs738409, located in the PNPLA3 gene, was associated with the development and severity of MAFLD. Moreover, this genotype was linked to a modest protective effect against CAD by impacting triglyceride metabolism, adding to the understanding of its dual role in both conditions.
title: Genome-wide insights into the shared genetic landscape between metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease and cardiovascular diseases

finding: rs199612805 was located near ADORA2A, which encodes a receptor inhibited by caffeine. This SNP was associated with coffee intake and had earlier links to caffeine intake from both tea and coffee in the UK Biobank, marking it as a significant finding.
title: Genome-Wide Association Studies of Coffee Intake in UK/US Participants of European Ancestry Uncover Gene-Cohort Influences

finding: The study found that the PNPLA3 rs738409 GG homozygous variant was associated with an increased risk of liver fibrosis and further amplified the risk of heart failure, with a significant interaction noted between this SNP and liver fibrosis assessed by FIB-4 and APRI scores. Notably, it was confirmed that this genetic variant is associated with increased risk of more advanced liver diseases, particularly in the context of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
title: Liver fibrosis assessed using non-invasive markers and genetic polymorphisms (PNPLA3 and TM6SF2) predisposing to liver fibrosis, is associated with hospitalization or death from heart failure: a prospective UK Biobank study

finding: The SNP rs73885319 was part of the G1 risk variants associated with APOL1 gene. It was shown that cells carrying this variant exhibited depressed baseline and maximum mitochondrial oxygen consumption as well as impaired mitochondrial networking, indicating a dysfunction that contributed to endothelial cytotoxicity.
title: APOL1 variant-expressing endothelial cells exhibit autophagic dysfunction and mitochondrial stress

finding: Similar to rs73885319, SNP rs60910145 was also identified as a part of the G1 risk variants of APOL1. Cells with this SNP demonstrated defects in mitochondrial respiration and compromised autophagic flux, implicating its role in lysosomal dysfunction linked to the pathology of SLE.
title: APOL1 variant-expressing endothelial cells exhibit autophagic dysfunction and mitochondrial stress

finding: The SNP rs71785313 was part of the G2 risk variants in the APOL1 gene. Its associated HUVEC cells showed comparable mitochondrial dysfunction and lysosome integrity issues, suggesting a significant contribution to endothelial cellular stress and potential pathology in diseases such as SLE.
title: APOL1 variant-expressing endothelial cells exhibit autophagic dysfunction and mitochondrial stress

finding: The SNP rs3915951, an exonic missense variant in CYP2D6, was heterozygous in a single Papuan, highlighting its potential significance in that population with a CADD score ≥ 20.
title: Archaic introgression and variation in pharmacogenes and implications for local adaptation

finding: The variant rs5756095 was found to create a predicted splicing acceptor site, resulting in increased splicing in the carriers of this allele. This change was significant enough to explain the differential expression observed in MPRA measurements.
title: U-rich elements drive pervasive cryptic splicing in 3’ UTR massively parallel reporter assays

finding: The rs738409 polymorphism in the PNPLA3 gene was associated with liver damage and the development of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This finding indicated that genetic variations in PNPLA3 could significantly influence an individual's risk of developing fatty liver disease, which has relevance in understanding the pathogenesis of similar conditions such as alcohol-induced liver disease.
title: Modeling alcoholic liver disease in a human Liver-Chip

finding: The SNP rs77968014-G in the gene SLC16A8 was implicated in deficits in transepithelial lactate transport in iPSC-derived retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells from individuals carrying the risk allele. This finding contributed to the understanding of how genetic variations can impact cellular function and metabolic handling in RPE cells, ultimately providing insights into the mechanisms underlying AMD pathology.
title: Transcriptomic changes predict metabolic alterations in LC3 associated phagocytosis in aged mice

finding: TP rs11479 was associated with a lower treatment response linked to a specific amino acid change, providing insights into pharmacogenomic factors influencing therapy success.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: The study identified that the nonsynonymous variant rs738409[G] in the PNPLA3 gene, which leads to an isoleucine-to-methionine substitution at position 148 (PNPLA3-I148M), was strongly associated with increased hepatic fat, making it the strongest known genetic risk factor for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD). The presence of this variant significantly increased both the risk and severity across various stages of liver disease, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.
title: The fatty liver disease-causing protein PNPLA3-I148M alters lipid droplet-Golgi dynamics

finding: The SNP rs78578513 was identified as part of a group of variants associated with the abundance of microbial populations in colorectal mucosa, demonstrating a possible link between genetic variation and colorectal cancer risk through microbiota modulation.
title: Gut microbiota composition in colorectal cancer patients is genetically regulated

finding: Similar to rs78578513, rs5994535 was also found to be associated with microbial abundance, indicating a potential role of this variant in the context of colorectal cancer risk via its influence on gut microbiota.
title: Gut microbiota composition in colorectal cancer patients is genetically regulated

finding: For the COMT rs4680 polymorphism, G/G genotype subjects showed a greater increase in C-peptide levels after ARI treatment compared to A allele carriers. This indicated that the G allele may influence the metabolic response during antipsychotic treatment.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The COMT rs13306278 T carriers experienced significantly higher increases in C-peptide levels following aripiprazole treatment compared to A carriers. This finding pointed towards its influence on glucose metabolism in the context of antipsychotic use.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The SNP was identified as a cis-rQTL for BCR when associated with NFATC1. This finding suggested functional links among a network of proteins related to NFATC1 and its potential implications in drug development.
title: Genetic associations with ratios between protein levels detect new pQTLs and reveal protein-protein interactions

finding: The SNP rs9306335, with T/C variants, was identified in an intergenic enhancer Alu element. This enhancer was linked to four potential target genes: TAB1, MGAT3, MIEF1, and RPS19BP1. The association of this SNP was particularly noted in relation to the glycosylation of immunoglobulin, as annotated in the GWAS catalog. In terms of gene function, TAB1 is recognized as an immune-related gene while MGAT3 functions as a glycosylase essential for the glycosylation process of immunoglobulin. The alignment of the T and C variants with target genes and eRNA revealed discrepancies where the genes showed mismatches and perfect matches in BLAST alignment.
title: Evidences for functional trans-acting eRNA-promoter R-loops at Alu sequences

finding: The SNP rs5758389 was linked to the ACO2 gene, which is crucial for the TCA cycle. The study predicted that ACO2 expression would be downregulated in Europeans and upregulated in Native American populations, particularly Peruvians from Lima (PEL). This prediction was attributed to multiple SNP effects, with rs5758389 being a dominant factor contributing to the expression variation.
title: A gene-level test for directional selection on gene expression

finding: CYP2D6*17 (rs28371706) had a high frequency of 0.2306 in the African populations, associated with decreased CYP2D6 enzymatic activity in African Bantu populations, marking it as a significant pharmacogenomic variant.
title: The extent and impact of variation in ADME genes in sub-Saharan African populations

finding: This SNP was previously associated with heart rate (P = 1.6 x 10^-9) and was observed to form a cardiac specific loop to the promoter of the GJA1 gene, which encodes connexin 43.
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: The study observed that individuals carrying the C allele at rs2267447 had significantly lower resting-state functional connectivity (rs-FC) between the right insula and left putamen, with a p-value of 6.17 x 10^-5, suggesting its involvement in pain sensitivity pathways.
title: A Brain-Wide Genome-Wide Association Study of Candidate Quantitative Trait Loci Associated with Structural and Functional Phenotypes of Pain Sensitivity

finding: Data revealed that the A allele of rs1081003 was associated with reduced rs-FC strength between the right insula and left putamen for high pain sensitivity individuals, with a significance level indicated by p = 6.08 x 10^-5.
title: A Brain-Wide Genome-Wide Association Study of Candidate Quantitative Trait Loci Associated with Structural and Functional Phenotypes of Pain Sensitivity

finding: The rs6971 SNP resulted in the A147T polymorphism of the TSPO gene, which compromised the binding of TSPO ligands utilized for PET imaging to visualize neuroinflammation. The polymorphism was prevalent in Caucasian populations, with around 10% being homozygous and up to 30% heterozygous carriers. Additionally, this variant not only diminished ligand binding affinities but also was linked to increased risk of neurological disorders like bipolar disorder, demonstrating its significance in functional cellular mechanisms.
title: Differential mitochondrial protein interaction profile between human translocator protein and its A147T polymorphism variant

finding: SNP rs3827354, associated with the phospholipase A2 Group VI, demonstrated connections to oxylipin metabolism and was implicated in the mechanisms affecting hemolysis susceptibility.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: The SNP rs714024 was identified as differentially imbalanced for chromatin in renal cell carcinoma (RCC) tumors and was associated with the expression of the GRAMD4 gene, showing significant evidence as an eQTL in tumor samples. This SNP resided in a differentially active super-enhancer, highlighting its role in cancer gene regulation.
title: Allelic imbalance reveals widespread germline-somatic regulatory differences and prioritizes risk loci in Renal Cell Carcinoma

finding: The SNP rs738409 showed a strong association with liver fat and was consistent with previously established links to NAFLD, reinforcing its impact on liver health.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs855791 was associated with liver iron levels and had significant previous reports linking it to related traits.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The variant rs201455670 was identified in the L1-5219 locus and specifically changed threonine at the 655th position of the L1 ORF2p protein to proline. This mutation was significant as it occurred in a critical region necessary for L1 retrotransposition, leading researchers to believe it could render L1-5219 incompetent for retrotransposition. This alteration was shown to reduce retrotransposition efficiency by approximately 90%, supporting its role in preventing somatic L1 insertions in patients with high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC). The variant was noted both in clinical tumor samples that did not exhibit somatic L1 insertions and in the Kuramochi cell line, which also lacked somatic L1-5219 mediated insertions.
title: L1 retrotransposition is regulated post-transcriptionally In High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer

finding: The SNP rs35898507 was identified within the uORF of A3F mRNA, associated with a common variant that caused an amino acid change from Glycine (G) to Valine (V). The study indicated that this SNP had a Minor Allele Frequency (MAF) greater than 0.01, with G being the ancestral allele present in over 96% of the population. Although this SNP was common, no variants were discovered in the A3G uORF that exceeded a MAF of 0.005, and the conservation of the identified uORFs in A3G and A3F was highlighted as significant in the human population.
title: A conserved uORF impacts APOBEC3G translation and is essential for translational inhibition by the HIV-1 Vif protein

finding: This SNP showed associations with the expression of the KREMEN1 gene and distal gene expressions (RHBDD3 and EWSR1) located 200 kb away but within the same TAD.
title: Disease and phenotype relevant genetic variants identified from histone acetylomes in human hearts

finding: Associated with the expression of the distal gene NIPSNAP1, rs713657 was involved in significant expression correlations lying within the same TAD.
title: Disease and phenotype relevant genetic variants identified from histone acetylomes in human hearts

finding: This SNP also correlated with the expression of the distal gene NIPSNAP1, 235 kb away, within the same TAD
title: Disease and phenotype relevant genetic variants identified from histone acetylomes in human hearts

finding: The polymorphism rs139883 in the SOX10 gene was found to be associated with the age of onset of schizophrenia specifically in a Han Chinese population, marking it as a positive original finding connecting genetic variation to a clinical phenotype.
title: SOX10 Expression Levels may be a Critical Mediator of White Matter Dysfunction in Schizophrenia

finding: This SLE-associated variant exhibited stronger enhancer activity for the non-risk 'A' allele compared to the risk 'G' allele, aligning with its role as an eQTL for SYNGR1.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The SNP rs4680 of the catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) gene was analyzed as part of a risk combination for L-TRS. The combination with Met(-) allele demonstrated potential predictive value regarding schizophrenia risk, indicating that this allele might reflect increased COMT activity.
title: Genetic combination risk for schizophrenia

finding: The SNP rs177425 was one of the top tag SNVs for a significant hastening modifier effect (22AM1) at MED15, showing genome-wide significance for age at TFC6 (p=5.0E-09), but not for age at motor onset (p=7.7E-02), underscoring the complexity of genetic influences on Huntington's disease phenotypes.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs165666, along with rs177425, was part of the significant modifier effect (22AM1) at MED15 that influenced age at TFC6, further demonstrating the genetic interplay affecting timing in Huntington's disease.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs8137409 was identified as significant in a new landmark-delaying effect (22BM1) in chromosome 22, emphasizing genetic modulation of disease timing.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs59906307 contributed to the modifier effect at the 22BM1 locus alongside rs8137409, revealing its significance in modifying Huntington's disease progression.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs4680 in the COMT gene was associated with differences in susceptibility to drug addiction behaviors, as documented in a study involving synthetic cannabinoid use disorder patients. This finding suggested a role in modulating behavioral responses linked to internalizing disorders.
title: Bioenergetic-Related Gene Expression in the Hippocampus Predicts Internalizing vs. Externalizing Behavior in a F2 Cross of Selectively-Bred Rats

finding: The SNP rs77601382 was identified as significant in association with nonverbal reasoning performance, located within the 3’ end of the FBLN1 gene. Its association suggested a link between FBLN1 variation and psychotic disorders, emphasizing the importance of this gene in neurodevelopment.
title: Genetics and Pathway Analysis of Normative Cognitive Variation in the Philadelphia Neurodevelopmental Cohort

finding: Similar to rs77601382, the SNP rs74825248 also passed the genome-wide significance threshold in relation to nonverbal reasoning, reinforcing the potential role of FBLN1 genetic variation in cognitive functions and its implications for psychotic disorder risk.
title: Genetics and Pathway Analysis of Normative Cognitive Variation in the Philadelphia Neurodevelopmental Cohort

finding: The SNP rs5765534 was associated with nonverbal reasoning and met the genome-wide significance criteria. Its location in proximity to FBLN1 suggests that variations at this locus may affect neurodevelopmental processes and relate to cognitive abilities linked to psychosis.
title: Genetics and Pathway Analysis of Normative Cognitive Variation in the Philadelphia Neurodevelopmental Cohort

finding: The rs1936950 variant was identified as a causal variant associated with increased expression of the ESS2 gene in the cerebral hemisphere. Its activating allele significantly increased transcription over baseline by a delta log2 activity of 0.51.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The rs1936951 variant was also causally linked to increased ESS2 expression, with an activating allele that exhibited a delta log2 activity of 1.41. Together, the combined alleles of rs1936950 and rs1936951 had a greater effect than the additive contributions, indicating a synergistic interaction.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The rs35742686 (2549delA) variant was positively associated with increased levels of enzymatic activity of the CYP2D6 enzyme. This finding suggested that individuals with this variant exhibited enhanced attentional processes, as indicated by cortical activity in brain regions related to spatial attention.
title: Effects of genetic variability of CYP2D6 on neural substrates of sustained attention during on-task activity

finding: The rs1065852 (100C>T) polymorphism was found to correlate with high enzymatic activity of the CYP2D6 enzyme, which was associated with increased recruitment of neural substrates involved in attentional tasks during cognitive performance.
title: Effects of genetic variability of CYP2D6 on neural substrates of sustained attention during on-task activity

finding: The rs3892097 (1846G>A) variant showed a positive association with higher CYP2D6 enzymatic activity. This polymorphism’s influence indicated differential brain activity patterns related to attentional engagement, particularly favoring rapid metabolizers.
title: Effects of genetic variability of CYP2D6 on neural substrates of sustained attention during on-task activity

finding: The rs5030655 (1707delT) variant had a positive correlation with lower levels of enzymatic activity, suggesting that poor metabolizers demonstrated enhanced reward-related modulation of cortical activity, implying a variation in cognitive efficiency during attentional tasks.
title: Effects of genetic variability of CYP2D6 on neural substrates of sustained attention during on-task activity

finding: The rs28371725 (2988G>A) was positively related to elevated CYP2D6 activity levels, which contributed to differential brain activation patterns when engaging in spatial attentional tasks, thereby affecting cognitive efficiency.
title: Effects of genetic variability of CYP2D6 on neural substrates of sustained attention during on-task activity

finding: The variant rs1004763 located in 22q13.1 showed a positive association with various FA measures related to white matter microstructure.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: Variant rs2267161 in 22q12.2 demonstrated significant associations with non-FA measures, affecting the white matter microstructure.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: The SNP rs6010240 was associated with the expression of gelatinase B/MMP-9, an important factor in tumor pathogenesis and progression. The analysis indicated that variants at this locus contributed to the phenotype of diverse EMT characteristics in breast cancer, potentially influencing patient survival outcomes by modulating motility and invasive properties of tumor cells.
title: Combinatorial perturbation analysis reveals divergent regulations of mesenchymal genes during epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition

finding: The SNP rs6010376 was positively associated with glioblastoma in the study by Kim et al. (2014). It was indicated that the activation of STAT3 in glioblastoma had significant biochemical and therapeutic implications. The findings related to this SNP suggested that it may play a role in the aggressive behavior of glioblastoma, similar to the implications observed with Piezo1.
title: The mechanoreceptor PIEZO1 is a novel oncogene in glioma by promoting astrocyte reactivity

finding: The SNP rs138880 was associated with the BRD1 promoter regions in the context of schizophrenia. This finding suggested that the risk allele for this SNP was linked to alterations in DNA methylation patterns, which could impact gene expression and contribute to the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
title: Identification of DNA motifs that regulate DNA methylation

finding: The variant rs1547014 was found to be associated with the expression of CHEK2 in hepatocytes across genotypes related to MASLD. The C allele of this eSNP was identified as a risk allele, exhibiting decreased expression of CHEK2, which plays a critical role in DNA damage response and has implications for hepatocarcinogenesis.
title: Identification of genes conferring individual-level variation responsible for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis using single-cell eQTL analysis

finding: Splicing assessment indicated that the SNP rs2072049 might lower the efficiency of normal splice site recognition, thus potentially leading to decreased expression, although this was not statistically significant.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: The SNP rs6003906 was linked to intron retention phenomena, with independent confirmation derived from RNAseq indicating its role in altering normal splicing patterns.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: This SNP significantly increased the frequency of exon skipping in the <italic>ARFGAP3</italic> gene, validated through both q-RT-PCR and microarray studies.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: The SNP rs17002806 revealed evidence of alternative exon usage driven by changes in splice site strength, leading to increased exon skipping.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: This SNP caused an increase in exon skipping likely due to the compromised definition of upstream splice sites, as shown by microarray and q-RT-PCR findings.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: This variant was shown to activate a downstream cryptic splice site, linked to observations of increased exon skipping in related RNAseq analyses.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: The SNP rs12628403 served as a proxy for the APOBEC3B deletion and was associated with decreased levels of APOBEC3B expression in both tumor and normal tissues within luminal breast cancer patients. This association validated the SNP's role in studying immune gene profiles and mutational events. Although a slight increase in the frequency of the deletion allele was observed in high-TIL patients compared to other luminal immune subtypes, the difference lacked statistical significance. Additionally, expression levels of the APOBEC3A_B hybrid transcript showed no variation across immune subtypes, and ESTIMATE immune scores remained consistent across different genotypes of SNP rs12628403.
title: Immune gene expression profiling reveals heterogeneity in luminal breast tumors

finding: SNP rs35570734 showed correlations with decreased SA in perirhinal cortex for ASD, revealing its genetic importance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs5753507 was associated with increased temporal pole SA for BD, showcasing its genetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The rs738409 SNP, a common missense variant (Ile148Met) in the PNPLA3 gene, was robustly associated with a 2.2% increase in ALT and a 1.3% increase in AST, known to enhance the risk of liver disease significantly.
title: Genome-wide association study of circulating liver enzymes reveals an expanded role for manganese transporter SLC30A10 in liver health

finding: The SNP 2851C>T (rs16947) in CYP2D6, known as R296C, exhibited a high frequency of approximately 0.3 to 0.4 and was associated with a pronounced functional consequence, specifically a largely decreased turnover rate, which indicated its significance in the metabolism of both ketamine and amitriptyline.
title: Non-additivity of the functional properties of individual P450 species and its manifestation in the effects of alcohol consumption on the metabolism of ketamine and amitriptyline

finding: The SNP 100C>T (rs1065852) in CYP2D6, labeled P34S, also had a high frequency of about 0.2 and demonstrated substantial functional consequences, primarily a decreased turnover rate, which contributed to its relevance in drug metabolism.
title: Non-additivity of the functional properties of individual P450 species and its manifestation in the effects of alcohol consumption on the metabolism of ketamine and amitriptyline

finding: This SNP was linked to significant associations with CD8 T-cells and T-central memory cell LSES, and also showed suggestive associations with T-helper cell signatures.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with T-central memory cell LSES, showcasing its importance in T-cell immune responses.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP, associated with a loss-of-function variant in CHEK2, conferred an approximately 2.3-fold increased risk of breast cancer. It was correlated with other LOY-associated variants and demonstrated relevance towards non-haematological cancer susceptibility, emphasizing its role in cancer risk assessment in relation to LOY.
title: Genetic predisposition to mosaic Y chromosome loss in blood is associated with genomic instability in other tissues and susceptibility to non-haematological cancers

finding: The SNP rs7291467 was identified as a significant genetic variant affecting galectin-2 expression, which plays a role as an inhibitor of arteriogenesis. This finding provided insights into the influence of this polymorphism on cardiovascular health and disease, linking it to human cardiovascular phenotypes.
title: Natural genetic variation quantitatively regulates heart-rate and -dimension

finding: Found in the ASCC2 gene, this SNP showed the strongest association with LDL and total cholesterol, contributing to lipid phenotype associations.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: In the context of WHRadjBMI GWAS, rs2294239 was identified as the lead variant for signal 1, colocalizing with eQTL data, indicating a strong association with adiposity metrics.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: The second signal for WHRadjBMI was identified as rs5762906, which also colocalized with eQTL signals, further elucidating regulatory mechanisms involving obesity traits.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: The rs6971 SNP was associated with the translocator protein (TSPO) polymorphism, which influenced binding affinity status. Specifically, this polymorphism characterized low-affinity binding status (LAB), medium-affinity binding status (MAB), and high-affinity binding status (HAB) in relation to PET biomarkers in the tumor microenvironment. This finding was important for glioblastoma diagnosis and specifically related to the cellular allocation of PET signals in tumor cells versus tumor-associated microglia/macrophages.
title: Deciphering sources of PET signals in the tumor microenvironment of glioblastoma at cellular resolution

finding: This SNP was associated with monocyte count and demonstrated its role as an eQTL for IL17RA primarily in the brain cortex and other brain tissues.
title: Genome-Wide Large-Scale Multi-Trait Analysis Characterizes Global Patterns of Pleiotropy and Unique Trait-Specific Variants

finding: The variant rs7288455 was linked to increased expression of the gene CACNA1I across all cell populations. The reference A allele was predicted to decrease expression, while the C or G variants were associated with increased expression, particularly in Sst Chodl cells. The variant was also noted to overlap with an ENCODE cis-regulatory element, reinforcing its predicted influence on gene expression.
title: Predicting cell population-specific gene expression from genomic sequence

finding: The SNP rs1061325, which results in a methionine to valine substitution at position 1316 (M1316V) of the CHC22 protein, was determined to have significant functional implications. The V1316 allele was predicted to be 'probably damaging' with a PolyPhen score of 0.975 and 'damaging' with SIFT, indicating a likely adverse effect on the protein's function related to GLUT4 membrane traffic in insulin response. This allele was more prevalent in farming populations compared to hunter-gatherers, suggesting that dietary transitions influenced the selection of this allele. The study hypothesized that ancient human diet changes, particularly with the advent of farming, exerted selective pressures favoring alleles that affect metabolic processes, thus impacting the human insulin response.
title: Genetic diversity of CHC22 clathrin impacts its function in glucose metabolism

finding: This SNP was involved in P1 blood group analysis, where lower accuracy indicated its potential non-causal status within the phenotypic framework.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Part of the three key SNPs contributing to P1 antigen expression, showcasing its relevance in phenotype discordances.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Identified within the P1 blood group analysis, this variant, along with others, showed significant concordance rates in antigen expression.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Participated in the prediction of P1 blood group phenotypes, where it accompanied other SNPs that had a high concordance with serological results.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: The SNP rs1210282, known as XPO1 E571K, was reported to modify the localization and interactome of Exportin 1 in B-Cell Lymphoma, indicating its significant role in altering protein transport mechanisms within the context of cancer pathology.
title: Protein-protein docking analysis reveals efficient binding and complex formation between the human nuclear transport proteins

finding: The SNP rs760294168 corresponds to a pathogenic variant in the mtFAS gene MCAT, specifically c.812T>C; p.T271I. This variant was observed to cause perturbed electron transport chain (ETC) complex assembly and impaired cellular respiration in human subjects. Furthermore, parallels were drawn to similar phenotypes arising from disrupted Aasdhppt expression in mouse skeletal myoblasts, indicating possible shared pathway dysfunctions.
title: Mitochondrial Phosphopantetheinylation is Required for Oxidative Function

finding: The I148M variant of PNPLA3 (rs738409) was strongly associated with an increased susceptibility to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in humans. The study revealed that this variant acted as a gain-of-function inhibitor of ATGL (adipose triglyceride lipase), leading to impaired hepatic triglyceride (TG) secretion and contributing to the development of hepatic steatosis.
title: Substrate-Specific Function of PNPLA3 Facilitates Hepatic VLDL-Triglyceride Secretion During Stimulated Lipogenesis

finding: SNP rs1555188 was negatively associated with Eubacterium rectale in females, indicating a potential regulatory mechanism underlying gut dysbiosis.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: SNP rs35928604 associated with PARVB gene exhibited strong links with colorectal cancer, highlighting the importance of genetic factors influencing gut microbiome-related oncogenic pathways.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs738409, associated with the PNPLA3 gene, was previously identified as having an effect on the gut microbiota and was linked to the severity of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in obese youth. The context of the finding suggested its relevance in understanding how genetic factors might interplay with chemotherapy-induced intestinal injury and microbiota changes, particularly in the setting of colorectal cancer treatments.
title: Chemotherapy drugs induce different gut microbiota disorder pattern and NODs/RIP2/NF-κB signaling pathway activation that lead to different degrees of intestinal injury

finding: The rs738409 SNP, located at the PNPLA3 locus, was previously identified as a genetic variant associated with hepatic steatosis. In the study, individuals with the NASH-prone (NP) phenotype exhibited higher levels of liver steatosis compared to those with the NASH-resistant (NR) phenotype, suggesting that this variant may contribute to the progression from NAFLD to more severe NASH.
title: Super-enhancer signature reveals key mechanisms associated with resistance to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis in humans with obesity

finding: The SNP rs5760147 was identified as the lead eQTL associated with the gene GSTT1 in most RPE subpopulations, supporting its role in geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: For the Progenitor RPE subpopulation, the SNP rs6003988 served as the lead eQTL associated with GSTT1, indicating its significance in genetic regulation related to geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: In the RPE6 subpopulation, rs2097433 emerged as the lead eQTL for the gene GSTT1, which is pertinent to the understanding of geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs5765545 on chromosome 22 was associated with the planum temporale.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: The SNP chr22:14573586:C:CCCGAGAG is synonymous with rs519400784 and reflects its classification as a high-confidence variant based on its association with regulatory signals in cattle, underlining its potential impact on production traits.
title: Annotation and assessment of functional variants in regulatory regions using epigenomic data in farm animals

finding: The SNP rs9612520 was associated with the eQTL signal for DDTL, showing a significant interaction with cardiac stage indicating its expression is differentially associated with genotype between iPSC-CVPC and adult heart samples.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The rs5764238 single nucleotide variant was reported to have a significant allelic effect on SPI1 binding in a binding quantitative trait locus (bQTL) study. It was found that the alternate G allele increased SPI1 ChIP-seq and ATAC-seq signal by creating a stronger SPI1 motif, as demonstrated through the predictions made by BPNet models using ChIP-seq and ATAC-seq profiles.
title: The dynseq genome browser track enables visualization of context-specific, dynamic DNA sequence features at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The study revealed that among the participants, A-allele carriers of the COMT A/G rs4680 SNP exhibited a significantly higher prevalence of physical activity (PA), especially among those engaged in running. In detail, 83% of highly active women carried the A-allele compared to only 47% of the low active group. The findings suggested that A-allele carriers had increased dopamine levels due to lower enzymatic activity, which might enhance their PA practices and motivations, particularly for running. Furthermore, A-allele carriers showed significantly elevated scores in various PA indexes compared to non-carriers.
title: The association of catechol-O-methyltransferase genetic polymorphism rs4680 in physical activity among adult women

finding: The SNP rs6010366 was studied in relation to its association with matrix metalloproteinases in colorectal cancer. The findings indicated that variations in the expression of MMP-9 were significant, particularly as higher mRNA and protein expression levels were noted in the tumor samples of patients with colorectal carcinoma. The research suggested that this SNP may be linked to the progression of CRC, given the role of MMP-9 in tumor proliferation and invasion.
title: Extracellular matrix changes in colorectal carcinoma and correlation with lymph node metastasis

finding: The SNP rs4680 in the COMT gene was associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD). This SNP was particularly noteworthy as COMT is actively discussed as a therapeutic target for AD and is also known to be the target of the anti-Parkinson drug Tolcapone, highlighting the cross-disease relevance of this finding.
title: GuiltyTargets: Prioritization of Novel Therapeutic Targets with Deep Network Representation Learning

finding: The SNP rs397514502 was associated with a rare enzyme variant of human A4galt, referred to as A4Gmut, which contained a p.Q211E substitution due to the c.631C>G mutation in the A4GALT gene. This variant enabled the enzyme to transfer galactose to GalNAc-terminating glycosphingolipids, resulting in the formation of NOR, NOR1, and NOR2 glycosphingolipids. Such findings contributed to understanding the enzymatic diversity and functional implications of A4galt in glycosphingolipid synthesis and its role in the P1PK histo-blood group system.
title: B4GALT5-deficient CHO-Lec2 cells expressing human α1,4-galactosyltransferase: a glycoengineered cell model for studying Shiga toxin receptors

finding: The SNP rs909685, located within the intron of the SYNGR1 gene, was identified as affecting susceptibility to rheumatoid arthritis (RA) through NK cell-specific mechanisms. This SNP was linked to increased expression levels of SYNGR1 and decreased methylation of a CpG site (cg19713460) associated with the gene, with robust evidence for colocalization with RA GWAS signals, emphasizing its functional role in inflammatory responses.
title: Interaction molecular QTL mapping discovers cellular and environmental modifiers of genetic regulatory effects

finding: SNP rs66534072 was significantly correlated with the 3'UTR usage of the UBE2L3 gene, where genetic variations were found to affect mRNA length and were particularly relevant to autoimmune disease contexts.
title: Genetic Basis of Alternative Polyadenylation is an Emerging Molecular Phenotype for Human Traits and Diseases

finding: Found in the MAPK1 locus, this variant was linked to T cell proliferation effects, suggesting its importance in T cell signaling cascades.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: The interaction between stress and the rs4633 genotype was found to significantly modify the risk of developing chronic primary pain conditions (CPPCs) in a sample of 482 cases and 208 controls. Individuals with two copies of the minor T allele in the high-stress group displayed trending increases in IL-6 and significant increases in IL-17A, aligning with findings from the associated mouse model that indicated elevated cytokine levels could serve as biomarkers for CPPCs.
title: A Novel Mouse Model of Chronic Primary Pain Conditions that Integrates Clinically Relevant Genetic and Environmental Factors

finding: Although the main effect of the rs4680 genotype was not significant in relation to CPPCs (P = 0.12), its high linkage disequilibrium with rs4633 allowed for its functional analysis. The T allele acted as a proxy for the Met allele characterized by reduced enzymatic activity, which suggested that the functional impact of genotype on stress interaction is relevant to pain condition development.
title: A Novel Mouse Model of Chronic Primary Pain Conditions that Integrates Clinically Relevant Genetic and Environmental Factors

finding: The SNP rs133376 was associated with schizophrenia (SCZ) through its identification in a genome-wide association study (GWAS). The findings indicated that this SNP influenced chromatin accessibility in specific brain regions, highlighting its role in neuropsychiatric disorders. The study utilized ATAC-seq data to evaluate the chromatin landscape surrounding this SNP, further illustrating its potential impact on gene regulation related to SCZ.
title: Transcriptome and chromatin accessibility landscapes across 25 distinct human brain regions expand the susceptibility gene set for neuropsychiatric disorders

finding: The COMT Val158Met (rs4680) polymorphism influenced local oscillation amplitudes and long-range temporal correlations (LRTCs). In contexts relating to brain function, Val158 homozygotes displayed higher COMT activity resulting in lower levels of dopamine (DA) and norepinephrine (NE) compared to Met158 homozygotes, contributing to individual variability in neuronal oscillation dynamics.
title: Genetic polymorphisms in COMT and BDNF influence synchronization dynamics of human neuronal oscillations

finding: The lead SNP rs7284877 located on chromosome 22q11.23 was identified as significant for DCM with an OR of 1.33 and p = 5.0 x 10^-10. It was found to be intronic to the gene SMARCB1, which also demonstrated strong expression regulation in cardiac tissues influenced by SNPs including rs7284877.
title: Genome wide association analysis in dilated cardiomyopathy reveals two new key players in systolic heart failure on chromosome 3p25.1 and 22q11.23

finding: The RNA editing QTL (rs202639) was associated with an intron retention event influenced by RNA editing in ZC3H7B, presenting evidence of its regulatory roles related to neurodegenerative disease.
title: Genetic control of RNA editing in Neurodegenerative disease

finding: The study categorized participants based on the rs6971 polymorphism of the TSPO gene into mixed-affinity binders (MABs) and high-affinity binders (HABs). This categorization played a role in understanding the variations in TSPO binding estimates, as it was considered alongside factors like age, BMI, and sex. The findings indicated that the genetic variation associated with rs6971 could influence the binding of the radioligand [11C]PBR28, thereby contributing to the variability in TSPO availability, which was assessed using PET imaging across healthy subjects.
title: Effects of age, BMI and sex on the glial cell marker TSPO - a multicentre [11C]PBR28 HRRT PET study

finding: This SNP was identified as having a significant effect on chromatin accessibility in the microglia-enriched Mic2 cluster. It disrupted the binding site for the FLI1 transcription factor, involved in microglia development. It was linked to the ARL4C gene, regulating lipid homeostasis in immune cells. Additionally, it was recognized as a lead MDD GWAS SNP, categorized as an eQTL and sQTL for several genes.
title: Differential Chromatin Architecture and Risk Variants in Deep Layer Excitatory Neurons and Grey Matter Microglia Contribute to Major Depressive Disorder

finding: The PNPLA3 rs738409 GG variant was associated with increased susceptibility to Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD) and correlated with disease progression to advanced conditions such as steatosis and fibrosis. Specifically, in the context of primary hepatocyte models, the presence of the GG variant was linked to elevated steatosis and immune activation compared to the CC wild type. This finding supported clinical observations of the GG variant's contribution to MASLD severity.
title: Comparison of Wild-Type and High-risk PNPLA3 variants in a Human Biomimetic Liver Microphysiology System for Metabolic Dysfunction-associated Steatotic Liver Disease Precision Therapy

finding: The fine-tuning of the GPT-4 model on dbSNP IDs for this variant achieved a prediction accuracy of 0.99 after optimizing the tokenization process by converting each ID into a single word represented by a token. This improvement indicated that the model effectively learned to identify the dbSNP ID, demonstrating the potential for high accuracy in variant annotation.
title: Boosting GPT Models for Genomics Analysis: Generating Trusted Genetic Variant Annotations and Interpretations through RAG and fine-tuning

finding: The rs131804 SNP, like rs11730091, was concordant with ZFX's binding motif and was also annotated as a GTEx eQTL in the heart, influencing genes such as GATB and TYMP. This suggests that it may play a critical role in regulating mitochondrial functioning and angiogenesis, particularly within the context of sex-specific differences in the human heart.
title: Statistical framework for calling allelic imbalance in high-throughput sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs5758550 was associated with the CYP2D6*2 phenotype, which affected the formation of endoxifen in breast cancer patients using tamoxifen, highlighting its significance in pharmacogenomics.
title: A unifying model to predict variable drug response for personalised medicine

finding: The SNP rs16947 was implicated in the CYP2D6 haplotypes as part of the CYP2D6*2 allele's categorization, showing its relevance for CYP2D6 genotyping panels.
title: A unifying model to predict variable drug response for personalised medicine

finding: The COMT Val108/158Met polymorphism (rs4680) was linked to differential learning biases. Specifically, homozygotes for the Met allele exhibited a lower learning bias regarding action-valence interactions, highlighting the role of this SNP in modulating prefrontal dopaminergic tone and its significance in the context of dopaminergic system variability and motivational learning.
title: Motivational learning biases are differentially modulated by genetic determinants of striatal and prefrontal dopamine function

finding: The novel SNP rs1004763 was associated with CT2 and showed a significance level of p=3.41×10−8. It is located near the SLC16A8 gene, although its relevance may be considered provisional until further replication.
title: Genomic Structural Equation Modeling Reveals Latent Phenotypes in the Human Cortex with Distinct Genetic Architecture

finding: The analysis revealed a 100% concordance between TaqMan and PharmacoScan genotyping for the SNP rs5758550 in the context of CYP2D6. This finding was significant as it demonstrated the reliability of these genotyping platforms for identifying variants associated with CYP2D6 enzyme activity, potentially impacting medication metabolism.
title: Cross-validation of technologies for genotyping CYP2D6 and CYP2C19

finding: The SNP rs6010240 was associated with the expression levels of MMP-9, a matrix metalloproteinase involved in tumor progression and invasion. The study referenced highlighted that increased levels of MMP-9 contribute to the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in breast cancer, which aligns with the observed effects of leptin on cell invasion and signaling pathway activation.
title: Leptin promotes expression of EMT-related transcription factors and invasion in a Src and FAK-dependent pathway in MCF10A mammary epithelial cells

finding: The SNP rs6010226 was associated with the expression of ELOVL2, which was found to be one of the most downstream enzymatic components in the fatty acid synthesis pathway that characterized cells with high tumorigenic potential in glioblastoma. The study indicated that higher expression of ELOVL2 corresponded with worsened patient survival, emphasizing its role in the metabolic pathways related to anti-oxidative, energetic, and cell membrane processes within the heterogeneous cell landscape of glioblastoma tumors.
title: Capture at the single cell level of metabolic modules distinguishing aggressive and indolent glioblastoma cells

finding: The rs9610686 SNP was identified as a top candidate hitchhiking with the nearby variant rs739042, which was a sweep-driving mutation in the analyzed risk loci.
title: Prioritising Autoimmunity Risk Variants for Functional Analyses by Fine-Mapping Mutations Under Natural Selection

finding: The rs739042 SNP was reported to be a sweep-driving mutation that was genetically linked with the hitchhiking SNP rs9610686.
title: Prioritising Autoimmunity Risk Variants for Functional Analyses by Fine-Mapping Mutations Under Natural Selection

finding: The rs4633 (H62H, C>T) silent variant was found to increase RNA abundance and protein abundance in HEK293 cells, demonstrating a notable influence on translation by relaxing secondary structure near the translation initiation site.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: The variant rs201641100 (P143P, C>T) was identified as contributing to increased RNA abundance, highlighting its impact on COMT expression.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: The study noted that rs8192488 (A146A, C>T) led to increased RNA abundance, thereby contributing positively to COMT expression levels.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: The rs758271838 (L60L, C>T) variant was linked to increased ribosome load, indicating a significant effect on translation efficiency.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: This variant, rs149909767 (G70R, G>A), also resulted in increased ribosome load, further underscoring its influence on the translation of COMT.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: The variant rs759340648 (D144N, G>A) was found to increase ribosome load, suggesting its role in enhancing COMT protein synthesis.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: The rs750684179 (G52G, T>C) variant decreased ribosome load and was predicted to alter RNA secondary structure, implicating its detrimental effect on COMT expression.
title: Integrated multiplexed assays of variant effect reveal cis-regulatory determinants of catechol-O-methyltransferase gene expression

finding: The SNP rs4680 is situated in the COMT gene locus and was associated with differential gene expression in the context of pain-related phenotypes. The analysis conducted through the Pain Signatures Database (TPSDB) showed that rs4680 was involved in the expression changes relevant to pain states, particularly in rodent dorsal root ganglion (DRG) tissues, highlighting its importance in inflammatory and neuropathic pain contexts.
title: The Transcriptomics Pain Signature Database

finding: The SNP rs1014971 was found to regulate the expression of the APOBEC3B (A3B) gene through an allele-specific effect on an enhancer located upstream of the APOBEC3 gene cluster. This regulation was significant in the context of bladder cancer, where an increased expression of the canonical A3B isoform, which encodes a mutagenic enzyme, was associated with poorer patient outcomes.
title: Isoform-specific characterization implicates alternative splicing in APOBEC3B as a mechanism restricting APOBEC-mediated mutagenesis

finding: The missense SNP rs139297 (Gly105Arg) was associated with the creation of an APOBEC3H protein isoform (A3H-I) that has nuclear localization. This finding was significant as it linked the presence of this variant to APOBEC-signature mutations detected in APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B-null breast and lung tumors, suggesting its role in influencing mutagenesis.
title: Isoform-specific characterization implicates alternative splicing in APOBEC3B as a mechanism restricting APOBEC-mediated mutagenesis

finding: SNP rs2331038 located in the LRP5L gene was associated with serotonin levels. This association was part of a larger trend where numerous genomic variants were discovered to be linked to various metabolites, enhancing the understanding of gut microbiota's influence on metabolite variation.
title: The faecal metabolome and its determinants in inflammatory bowel disease

finding: The SNP rs77563738, corresponding to the ADA2 deficiency with the mutation p.R169Q, was utilized in the study as a model for Inborn Errors of Immunity (IEI). The study reported achieving up to 80% bi-allelic editing of this mutation in patient T cells, resulting in functional correction of the disease phenotype. This demonstrated the effectiveness of homology-directed repair in correcting specific pathogenic variants.
title: T cell correction pipeline for Inborn Errors of Immunity

finding: The rs397514502 SNP represented a rare enzyme variant of A4galt characterized by a p.Q211E substitution. Found in only two families worldwide, this substitution significantly impacted the enzyme's acceptor specificity towards GalNAc-capped oligosaccharides, enabling the synthesis of NOR1 and NOR2 antigens. This finding was crucial as it provided insights into the variations in glycosylation processes influenced by the A4galt enzyme.
title: Delving into human α1,4-galactosyltransferase acceptor specificity: the role of enzyme dimerization

finding: The SNP rs738409, responsible for the I148M variant in the PNPLA3 gene, was identified as the most significant genetic risk factor for developing metabolic associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD). It functioned by sequestering the ABHD5 protein away from its interaction with PNPLA2, which is critical for TAG hydrolysis. This alteration due to I148M modified TAG metabolism in an ABHD5-dependent manner and promoted hepatosteatosis, highlighting a gain of function mutation related to liver steatosis.
title: Lipid Droplet Targeting of ABHD5 and PNPLA3 I148M is required to promote liver steatosis

finding: The SNP rs6519190 was found within the intron of the SYNGR1 gene, with associations to schizophrenia (SCZ). It was one of the eight lead SNPs linked to gene expression in brain tissues, contributing to the understanding of how creativity intersects with psychiatric vulnerabilities.
title: Genetic architecture of creativity and extensive genetic overlap with psychiatric disorders revealed from genome-wide association analyses of 241,736 individuals

finding: This SNP was associated with CYP2D6 and exhibited a concordance of less than 95%, attributed to reference inconsistencies and known structural variants affecting its dosage calls.
title: Development and validation of a pharmacogenomics reporting workflow based on the Illumina Global Screening Array chip

finding: Like rs1135840, this SNP was linked to CYP2D6, showing discrepancies between the microarray and reference calls due to structural variant implications.
title: Development and validation of a pharmacogenomics reporting workflow based on the Illumina Global Screening Array chip

finding: This SNP also related to CYP2D6, revealing similar discordances as rs1135840 and rs1058164, again highlighting structural variant influences on reported dosages.
title: Development and validation of a pharmacogenomics reporting workflow based on the Illumina Global Screening Array chip

finding: This variant was associated with the liver enzyme gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) and was noted as a significant signal in individuals of African ancestry, demonstrating a link between this genetic variant and hepatic function.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: The SNP rs11090045 was identified as the most significant SNP associated with the neuroticism general factor in the GWAS, showing a p-value of 4.0 x 10^{-13}. It is located in a gene-rich region on chromosome 22, overlapping with several candidate genes such as ZC3H7B and TEF, suggesting a potential biological basis linked to neuroticism.
title: Genetic and neural bases of the neuroticism general factor

finding: The rs6001946 SNP in the MKL1 gene was associated with schizophrenia in a Han Chinese population. This finding highlighted the potential link between MKL1 and neuronal signaling pathways, such as the MRTF-SRF pathway, which is crucial for brain development and function.
title: Cyclase-associated protein 1 (CAP1) represses MRTF-SRF-dependent gene expression in the mouse cerebral cortex

finding: The Valine allele of COMT Val158Met was significantly associated with greater susceptibility to framing effects in older adults. However, this association lost significance after adjustment for demographic covariates. The findings indicated that greater frontal dopamine concentrations linked to the COMT Met allele were protective against less consistent decision making.
title: COMT Val158Met polymorphism associated with greater susceptibility to framing effects in healthy older adults

finding: This rare intronic variant was found in samples with the *17 allele and had an allele frequency of approximately 1%. It was assigned as a new subvariant, *17.003, by PharmVar.
title: Nanopore sequencing of the pharmacogene CYP2D6 allows simultaneous haplotyping and detection of duplications

finding: This intronic variant was found in a sample matching to *41 and was categorized as a new subvariant *41.004, having an allele frequency of roughly 0.1%.
title: Nanopore sequencing of the pharmacogene CYP2D6 allows simultaneous haplotyping and detection of duplications

finding: This rare intronic variant had an allele frequency of 0.001% and was found in a sample with the *4 allele, leading to the assignment of a new subvariant *4.026.
title: Nanopore sequencing of the pharmacogene CYP2D6 allows simultaneous haplotyping and detection of duplications

finding: Identified as a rare upstream variant in four samples, it had an allele frequency of less than 1% and was assigned as a new subvariant *1.025.
title: Nanopore sequencing of the pharmacogene CYP2D6 allows simultaneous haplotyping and detection of duplications

finding: The SNP rs3747093 was shown to be within a 7-mer motif that could affect the DNaseI footprint for SCL/TAL. It demonstrated significant allelic imbalance in SCL/TAL ChIP-seq validations, indicating its involvement in erythroid transcriptional regulation.
title: An integrated platform to systematically identify causal variants and genes for polygenic human traits

finding: The variant rs855791 was associated with iron status, hemoglobin levels, and erythrocyte volume, as it is a missense variant in the TMPRSS6 gene. This gene plays a role in iron homeostasis regulation, further linking the variant to red blood cell characteristics.
title: An integrated platform to systematically identify causal variants and genes for polygenic human traits

finding: The I148M PNPLA3 variant (rs738409) was found to inhibit triglyceride hydrolysis, leading to the accumulation of the mutant PNPLA3 on lipid droplets and contributing to the liver disease severity in NAFLD patients.
title: TM6SF2/PNPLA3/MBOAT7 loss-of-function genetic variants impact on NAFLD development and progression both in patients and in in vitro models

finding: The SNP rs397514502 corresponded to a point mutation c.631C>G, which resulted in the protein substitution p.Q211E. This mutation had implications for the enzymatic activity of human Gb3/CD77 synthase, which was noted for its role in glycosylation processes associated with the human P1PK blood group system. The resulting protein variant, referred to as the E mutein, exhibited altered activity, particularly through the addition of galactose to a terminal GalNAc, leading to the formation of the rare NOR antigen.
title: Missing the sweet spot: one of the two N-glycans on human Gb3/CD77 synthase is expendable

finding: The SNP rs5758550, located in an enhancer region, was found to influence CYP2D6 haplotypes, which are critical for CYP2D6 genotyping panels. This finding indicated a significant relationship between genetic variants and pharmacogenetic outcomes in drug metabolism.
title: Hubble2D6: A deep learning approach for predicting drug metabolic activity

finding: The SNP rs16947, associated with the *2 allele, played a significant role in the classification of CYP2D6 haplotypes. This identified association emphasized the importance of this SNP in predicting metabolic activity and understanding patient responses to drugs.
title: Hubble2D6: A deep learning approach for predicting drug metabolic activity

finding: For the rs713875 SNP located near LIF and HORMAD2 loci, MENTR predicted a decrease in the expression of the enhancer ADDG22030591785.E in CD8+ T cells. Previous studies indicated the alternative allele was methylated in whole blood, supporting the findings by MENTR regarding its role in ncRNA expression regulation in specific immune cell types.
title: Predicting cell-type-specific non-coding RNA transcription from genome sequence

finding: The SNP rs139296, identified as a cis-eQTL for the gene APOBEC3D, showed that subjects homozygous for the major allele had lower transcript levels compared to heterozygotes or homozygotes for the minor allele, with a significant P value of < 0.01. This finding indicated the potential influence of this SNP on expression levels related to susceptibility or severity of viral infections.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: The SNP rs9611092 also acted as a cis-eQTL for APOBEC3D, with similar effects as rs139296, where homozygotes for the major allele had reduced transcript levels compared to heterozygotes or minor allele homozygotes. The statistical significance was recorded as P < 0.01.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: For the SNP rs139331, identified as a cis-eQTL for APOBEC3D, it presented lower expression levels in individuals homozygous for the major alleles when compared to others, with P < 0.01. This reinforced the association of this variant with the expression levels of APOBEC3D.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: The SNP rs8177832 served as a significant cis-eQTL for APOBEC3G. Findings indicated that homozygotes for the major allele had higher expression levels than heterozygotes and homozygotes for the minor alleles, with a P value of < 0.01.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: For rs17537581, it was observed as a cis-eQTL for APOBEC3G. Individuals homozygous for the major allele had significantly higher expression levels compared to heterozygotes or minor allele homozygotes, showing a P value of < 0.01. This finding was consistent with existing literature in other tissues.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: The SNP rs61362448, identified as a cis-eQTL for APOBEC3G, also exhibited higher expression in homozygotes of the major alleles compared to heterozygotes, with P < 0.05. This SNP contributed to understanding the genetic regulation of APOBEC3G expression.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: For rs738469, a cis-eQTL for APOBEC3G, it aligned with the findings that homozygotes for the major alleles exhibited higher expression levels compared to heterozygotes, with a significant P < 0.05. This SNP was important in modulating APOBEC3G expression.
title: Lung expression of genes encoding SARS-CoV-2 cell entry molecules and antiviral restriction factors: interindividual differences are associated with age and germline variants

finding: rs17879961 exhibited a strong association with the risk of TN disease (OR=0.61, P=2.55×10^-4) while also showing a strong association with luminal A-like disease, indicating opposite risk directions.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The SNP rs2269657 in the SREBF2 gene was associated with an increased risk of developing late onset Alzheimer's disease (AD). It was reported that SREBF2 mRNA levels were significantly higher in the temporal cortex and cerebellum of AD patients. Additionally, nuclear SREBP2, which is produced from SREBF2, exhibited a negative correlation with the presence of AT8-positive neurofibrillary tangles in the brains of individuals with AD. Furthermore, astrocyte-specific loss of SREBF2 led to defects in cholesterol synthesis, neurite outgrowth, behavior, and energy metabolism in mice, highlighting its critical role in cholesterol metabolism linked to AD pathology.
title: Regulation of astrocyte lipid metabolism and ApoE secretion by the microglial oxysterol, 25-hydroxycholesterol

finding: The study involved the analysis of the Ala147Thr polymorphism in the TSPO gene (rs6971), which is known to influence the binding affinity for TSPO radioligands like [11C]PBR28. Only individuals with the Ala/Ala or Ala/Thr genotypes (predicted high- and mixed-affinity binders) were included in the study, while those with the Thr/Thr genotype (predicted low-affinity binders) were excluded. This indicates that the findings related to neuroinflammation in PASC were potentially influenced by the genotypes that were analyzed, specifically in relation to the radioligand's binding characteristics.
title: Neuroinflammation in post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC) as assessed by [11C]PBR28 PET correlates with vascular disease measures

finding: The IL17RA rs4819554 polymorphism was associated with early-onset coronary artery disease, indicating a genetic basis for inflammation that may be relevant in the progression of GDM.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and signaling pathways in gestational diabetes mellitus by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs73885319, which corresponds to the mutation 1024A→G in the APOL1 gene, was determined to have the highest de novo origination rate and deviated significantly from the genome-wide average rate for its A→G type. It was found to originate significantly more frequently in Africans, the population where it is of adaptive significance, as it provides protection against African sleeping sickness while imparting an increased risk for chronic kidney disease (CKD) in homozygotes.
title: De novo rates of a Trypanosoma-resistant mutation in two human populations

finding: The SNP rs60910145, related to the APOL1 G1 variant (mutating codon 384 from Isoleucine to Methionine), was observed in conjunction with rs73885319. While specific details about its de novo mutation rate were not highlighted independently, it was emphasized that both homozygotes and heterozygotes for rs73885319 (1024A→G) were asymptomatic for Trypanosoma brucei gambiense. This indicates its role in providing protection against African sleeping sickness.
title: De novo rates of a Trypanosoma-resistant mutation in two human populations

finding: The SNP rs71785313 corresponds to a 6 nucleotide in-frame deletion resulting in the absence of Asparagine and Tyrosine at codons 388 and 389 in the APOL1 gene. Similar to rs73885319, it was recognized for its protective effect against Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, with no infections occurring in homozygotes or heterozygotes. This SNP is prevalent in populations from sub-Saharan Africa, contributing to the adaptive significance of the G2 variant.
title: De novo rates of a Trypanosoma-resistant mutation in two human populations

finding: The study found that individuals with the Met allele (homozygous for the Val or Met alleles) of the COMT polymorphism (rs4680) were invited to participate in the remainder of the study, suggesting a specific focus on how this allele impacted behavioral control and model-based decision-making processes.
title: A dopaminergic basis of behavioral control

finding: The rs4821699 SNP, located in an intron of TRIOBP on chromosome 22, was associated with glaucoma and was most accessible in retinal ganglion cells, the primary cell type affected during glaucoma. It was predicted to alter TRIOBP expression, suggesting a role in glaucoma pathology.
title: Single-cell multiome of the human retina and deep learning nominate causal variants in complex eye diseases

finding: SNP rs11705619 was linked to gene TXNRD2, noted for its association with multiple genetic conditions.
title: Locating suspicious lethal genes by abnormal distributions of SNP patterns

finding: The PNPLA3 rs738409 variant was associated with an increased risk of liver toxicity in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) treated with beta-interferon.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs17000526 variant, associated with APOBEC3B expression, was strongly linked with APOBEC signature mutations in bladder cancer with a regression coefficient of 0.21 (p = 1.81 × 10^-4). Additionally, a nominally significant association was found in ER+ breast tumors with a regression coefficient of 0.10 (p = 0.04), further implicating this variant in mutational signatures relevant to cancer.
title: Somatic mutational profiles and germline polygenic risk scores in human cancer

finding: The SNP rs117018441-T, located in an intron of CHADL, was associated with higher expression of CHADL compared to rs117018441-G in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. This finding indicated that increased expression of CHADL might negatively regulate both bone and cartilage, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for OA could involve inhibition of CHADL.
title: RNA sequencing reveals interacting key determinants of osteoarthritis acting in subchondral bone and articular cartilage

finding: The PNPLA3 rs738409 variant was identified as a strong genetic predictor of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study found that genetically instrumented hepatic steatosis significantly increased the risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D), with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.3 (95% CI: [1.2, 1.4], p=8.3e-14), indicating a clear causal relationship.
title: Mendelian Randomization Analysis Dissects the Relationship between NAFLD, T2D, and Obesity and Provides Implications to Precision Medicine

finding: The SNP rs738409 in the PNPLA3 gene was noted to differ among Prakriti types, indicating its relevance to conditions such as Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease, supporting Prakriti-based differentiation.
title: Genetic differences between extreme and composite constitution types from whole exome sequences reveal actionable variations

finding: The SNP rs11538371 was found to be linked to the gene TIMP3 in astrocytes. TIMP3 is an inhibitor of metalloproteinases, which are enzymes secreted by astrocytes. This relationship is particularly relevant in the context of Parkinson's Disease (PD), as TIMP3 is implicated in processes such as dopaminergic neuron degeneration, neuroinflammation, and proteolysis of alpha-synuclein.
title: RNetDys: identification of disease-related impaired regulatory interactions due to SNPs

finding: The SNP rs2072814 was identified as being associated with the gene TIMP3 in astrocytes. This finding is significant in relation to Parkinson's Disease (PD) and connects to the role of TIMP3 in inhibiting metalloproteinases, enzymes that contribute to neurodegenerative processes linked to PD.
title: RNetDys: identification of disease-related impaired regulatory interactions due to SNPs

finding: The SNP rs8137714 was linked to TIMP3 in astrocytes, with implications for Parkinson's Disease (PD) due to TIMP3's function as an inhibitor of metalloproteinases. These findings highlight the connection of this SNP with key pathological processes associated with PD.
title: RNetDys: identification of disease-related impaired regulatory interactions due to SNPs

finding: The rs755622 SNP was identified as associated with cardiovascular disease risk in individuals with TET2 clonal hematopoiesis (CH). The analysis of 340,766 participants in the UK Biobank demonstrated that the presence of the MIF risk allele (C) was linked to an elevated risk of incident coronary artery disease (CAD), with a hazard ratio of 1.42, indicating a significant interaction with TET2 CH but not with DNMT3A CH. This association was confirmed through adjusted models accounting for various cardiovascular risk factors.
title: Mutated cells mediate distinct inflammatory responses in clonal hematopoiesis

finding: The frequency of the variant within the APOL1 gene (rs73885319), which is linked to increased susceptibility to FSGS, HIVAN, and ESKD, demonstrated striking heterogeneity in ancestry-specific allele frequency estimates in the African/African American genetic ancestry group, which could not be resolved using just aggregate frequency estimates.
title: Improved Allele Frequencies in gnomAD through Local Ancestry Inference

finding: The study examined the Val158Met (rs4680) SNP within the COMT gene and found that heterozygote genotype carriers (Val/Met) exhibited significant amplitude enhancement of neural responses to deviant auditory stimuli compared to both homozygote carriers (Val/Val and Met/Met). This insight was crucial as it demonstrated how genetic variations in COMT could influence brain mechanisms underlying auditory predictive processing.
title: Association between COMT gene Val158Met heterozygote polymorphism and enhanced brain predicting processes

finding: The RA rs71312076 demonstrated significant regulatory effects in a massively parallel reporter assay, influencing gene regulation independently of any NDAs present. It showed substantial regulatory activity when analyzed in a non-introgressed European background, suggesting its role in restoring lost gene regulatory functions.
title: Neanderthal introgression reintroduced functional ancestral alleles lost in Eurasian populations

finding: The PNPLA3 rs738409 polymorphism was associated with the risk of NASH advanced liver fibrosis, illustrating its significance in liver disease contexts.
